author: ithinkimcrazy  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Jul 27, 2010 1:42 am Gender: Female
title: Unexplained Fat Gain In Just Three Weeks
content: I know that you see a lot of posts about weight gain.  But, I am scared.  I am a 28 y/o female with no real medical problems in my personal or family history.  I have no known food allergies (only a drug allergy to some narcotic painkillers) and am currently taking birth control.  I have been on the pill for over 8 years now.  I recently travelled to Hawaii for work and and have been here for the last three weeks.  For my entire life, I have tried to maintain an active lifestyle and a decent diet.  Two years ago, I lost approximately 30 pounds and went from 145 lbs (at 5'4") to 107 lbs (which was admittedly a little low for my body type).  In high school, I averaged around 120 lbs and maintain a pretty muscular physique.  When I got to Hawaii, I wanted to try and lose weight for my upcoming wedding and started focusing on working out, light lifts and lots of cardio.  I have been eating less than I did when I was back stateside and recently, I have seen myself developing a disturbing fatty layer in my stomach and just above my genital area.  The fat is different than I remember ever having and it has this permanent "muffin top" look to it (the two fat layers are separate) even when I am unclothed.  The fat in my lower abdomen is pretty jiggly and I can feel the movement when I run (which I never used to feel before).  The fat above my genitals is much thicker and has an odd consistency to it.  I have never seen my body look like this.  I understand that some of it is in my head... but not all.  This is starting to scare me.  I don't eat that much and I go to sleep feeling like a balloon that is about to pop.  It even hurts sometimes.  I can't get a good night's sleep.   I don't know if you need more information (I will be happy to provide it), but I am scared that there is something wrong.  And, I am even more scared that I won't be beautiful on my wedding day.  I would rather not get married than be fat in all my pictures.  But, most of all, I want to be able to run again without feeling my stomach jumping up and down.  I run about 5-6 miles 4-5 times per week and spend another 45 minutes in the gym on each day of the week.  Any advice, help, or explanations would be much appreciated.  I am scared for my health and for my wedding.  Thank you.
posted_time: Post  by ithinkimcrazy » Tue Jul 27, 2010 2:15 am

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Unexplained Fat Gain In Just Three Weeks
content: Hi, Although you have tried your best to describe the lesion, there is no substitute to a first hand clinical examination by a doctor. From the description given, one possibility could be one of several varieties of "Panniculitis" (inflammation of the subcuteneous fat).  This condition is classified in a number of different ways (clinical/microscopic). One such,classifies them based on the clinical presentation into - panniculitis with systemic disease and - panniculitis without systemic disease.  Several autoimmune disorders can be associated with panniculitis (ex., lupus erythematosus, scleroderma). One particular form is suspected to be having some unproven link to Electromagnetic radiation(Lipoatrophia Semicircularis).  Rather than to speculate, you should have yourself examined by a doctor to sort out this question. Good luck!

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: 31 yo female extreme fluid rentention
content: Hello,Though I can not profess to have a solution to your unexplained edema yet can offer you some diagnosis based on a reference.Idiopathic edema is a pitting edema of unknown cause that occurs primarily in pre-menopausal women who do not have evidence of heart, liver, or kidney disease. Idiopathic edema: I. The occurrence of hypoalbuminemia and abnormal albumin metabolism in women with unexplained edema  Volume 52, Issue 4, Pages 444-451 (April 1972)John R. Gill, M.D.1, Thomas A. Waldmann, M.D.1, Frederic C. Bartter, M.D.1 The American Journal of Medicine. The authors have found a significance of reduction of Albumen levels due to abnormal level of degradation of plasma albumin leading to edema in women who do not have other cardiovascular or kidney disease. This reduction leads to lowered blood volume signalling the secretion of aldosterone which in turn conserves sodium leading to odema.  In this condition diuretics seem to worsen the condition.ACE inhibitors,bromocriptine are some of the medications apart from withdrawal from diuretics. Do consult your doctor for more details.Best wishes

author: karate0kat  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Aug 18, 2010 9:42 am Gender: Female
title: Question about food intolerance
content: I'm a 22 year old female in pretty decent health considering I'm overweight.  When I was a kid could eat fish no problem.  We even took a family trip to the east coast where we ate almost nothing but fish, and I was fine.  When I was in my mid teens, however, I started having problems.  I had a bit of salmon at a party (we later confirmed no other guests got sick, so no food poisoning).  I went home and took a nap.  A couple hours after eating I started feeling extremely nauseous.  It kept getting worse.  It actually progressed a lot like labor, with the waves getting closer together and more intense as time went by.  After half an hour I was just dry heaving.  After two hours of continued dry heaving, and developing diarrhea, my mom took me to the hospital where they gave me compazine.  Months later the family had fish for dinner.  My mom has trouble with sea food too, so we just assumed the salmon had been salt water and she got us both fresh water trout.  Same thing.  So my doctor just told me not to eat anything that spends the majority of its time in water.  Then it happened after I had buckweat pancakes for breakfast one time.  No idea if that's connected to the fish thing or if I'm just lucky enough to have two intolerances (I have no trouble with any other kind of wheat, and buckwheat was the only ingredient I don't ingest on a regular or semi-regular basis).  But the really weird thing is that I can eat fake crab just fine.  Which is most commonly pollock, although it can be other things too and I don't know exactly what type the restaurant where I've had it uses.  So apparently some kinds of fish are OK?  Is there any way besides trial an error to figure out what fish I can safely eat?  I'm moving to the coast in a year, and since fish is a good healthy alternative and I'm trying to eat better (I'm 10 pounds away from no longer being obese!), and since super fresh fish is delicious, I'd really like to be able to eat some.  But I don't really enjoy having to go to the hospital to stop vomiting.    I'm guessing this is something I should probably work with an actual doctor with, but the other problem is that I never got a regular doctor after I moved to college, so I don't really have anyone I can talk to yet.  Is there a particular type of specialist I should look for?

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Question about food intolerance
content: Hi, There are two main health related concerns with regard to fish consumption. - seafood allergy and - ill effects due to contamination(ex., mercury).  Of late, fish and fish oils have raised some concerns. One major concern is that the fish from which the oils are manufactured may be poisoned with heavy metals and other marine pollutants. Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and mercury dioxins have been found in some species of fish.  It is well documented that both the atlantic and pacific salmon and other fish are increasingly being affected by marine pollution. Contamination by mercury has been a major concern. All salmonid fish require pure, well-oxygenated cold water and are one of the first species to suffer when water quality is degraded. Atlantic salmon are believed to be a symbol of clean, unspoiled waters that run wild to the sea.  Mercury has been noted to build up near salmon farms in fish feed and waste. Its biological availability is higher underneath fish-pen nets where ocean sediments become depleted of oxygen. This is thought to contaminate other types of fish as well.  The fish most affected by mercury contamination are those that eat other fish (piscivores), as living at the peak of the food web makes them vulnerable to accumulating persistent toxins like methylmercury. Mercury also has been observed to concentrate more in bigger fish.In one study among anglers in the 12 western states of the USA surveyed, fish such as rainbow and cutthroat trout were found to be the least contaminated of all. Only 2.3% of the stream lengths with members of the Salmonidae family contained fish too toxic for people to eat safely. Spencer A. Peterson, John Van Sickle, Alan T. Herlihy and Robert M. Hughes. 2007. Mercury Concentration in Fish from Streams and Rivers Throughout the Western United States. Environmental Science and Technology. 41(1): 58-65.  The symptoms of mercury poisoning include a metallic taste in the mouth, headaches, hearing loss, motor loss, and several others. Occasionally, it can cause irreparable damage to the heart and the nervous system.  In the east coast of USA, harmful cyanobacterial blooms (HCBs) have occurred in several large estuarine systems (e.g., Albemarle-Pamlico Sound, Chesapeake Bay, and Florida Bay). Cyanobacterial blooms are also serious problems in freshwater systems.They are known to occur in virtually every state in the US.They indicate excessive nutrient loading in water bodies.They have been found to be responsible for major estuarine fish and shellfish kills. In experimental studies, they have been reported to cause central nervous system dysfunction, including sudden rages and other erratic behavior, reversible cognitive impairment, chronic effects such as sustained asthma-like symptoms and suppressed immune system (may last for months to years).    Allergy to seafood (fish, crustaceans and molluscs) has nothing to do with iodine content. It is caused by specific IgE against allergenic proteins including, but not limited to, parvalbumins in fish and tropomyosins in crustaceans and molluscs. Cross-reactive allergy within each of these three groups of animals is common, but is less common between the groups. (Those allergic to prawns are often allergic to crab, but those allergic to crustaceans, are not usually allergic to fish.)While it is true that seafood may contain relatively high levels of iodine compared with other foods, the allergenic proteins are not iodinated and seafood allergy does not depend on the iodine content of the seafood.   It is also well known that stomach upsets are frequent side effects of fish oil supplements. Diarrhea may also occur, large doses capable of causing potentially severe episodes.There are also reports of increased acid reflux, increased belching, indigestion, flatulence and abdominal pain.However, mostly these side effects are associated with eating whole fish (potentially contaminated) rather than as the oil alone.  Your symptoms are more in favor of seafood allergy rather than mercury toxicity. It appears that you have allergy to certain fish, but not the crustaceans. You may even be allergic to salmon harvested from fish farms rather than the marine fish. I think that the local fisheries department may be able to provide you with more information. Good luck!

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: How many calories should a 5'1 female consume in a day?
content: Hello, The reason for the variation is because each individual is different in their metabolism and an estimate is the best we can do for people.  The idea is to get you into the ballpark range and then adjust as your needs require to lose 1-1/2 lbs. per week.  I would estimate this to be between 1500 and 1600 calories per day based on the information provided.    If you find this amount does not achieve the desired results, adjust it accordingly.  The goal is to have a healthy diet with the good carbs such as whole grains, fruits and vegetables along with reduced fat.  Make every calorie count for some good nutrition.  Also, be sure to drink plenty of water.  Your exercise regimen is quite good. Some aerobic exercises in the form of walking, jogging, bicycling or swimming would also help speed up your metabolism.  You should know that what you have done so far has already had a positive impact on your health so don't be discouraged that you aren't at goal yet.  Good luck in your efforts toward better health.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Aug 24, 2010 4:44 pm

author: Eramil  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Aug 10, 2010 1:54 pm Gender: Male
title: Can't Lose Weight - Sleep apnea, active, have seen 5 docs
content: The Issue: -I can't lose weight. For 7 months I have been trying, but after seeing 5 doctors, having my metabolism measured, exercising and dieting, nothing changes. I have apnea. Please see below for the whole story.   Background: -I am overweight (6'2", 285 lbs) but with lots of muscle (~25% body fat)... I bench 285-315, my heart is pretty healthy (resting bp is 110/70 to 130/85)  -I exercise frequently (2-4 times a week of intense weightlifting for 1.5 hrs or interval training with circuits for 1 hr, plus morning walks (0-3x week), weekend hikes,   -At age 16 (2000) I was 215lbs and fit, from there, went to 250, then 280. 2005 went back to 260, then gained to 280. After college (2007) had reached 290. In 6 months, through moderate diet and exercise, lost 50 lbs, back down to 240. Got married, had a few months of bad eating and gained it all back (back to 285 in June 2009). Since then, stuck on 285.   -I was diagnosed with sleep apnea (moderate to severe: 22-55 apneas/hr) in 2004. After a septoplasty in 2004, I was functional and fairly symptom free until June/july in 2009 (before it I slept 12-15 hrs/day and still was drowsing in class, after I was sleeping 9 hrs and staying awake much better, though I did start taking provigil 200mg about 2-4 times/week until 2007)  -prescribed a CPAP in 2004 at 10cmH2O, but for the 3 months i tried, i woke up with it off every night.   -August/September 2009 I began feeling extremely lethargic, mentally dull, and felt like I was losing my passion. This has worsened drastically since. The last few months I have felt like a zombie at work, with much of my drive, excitement and energy gone.   -started seeing a sleep dr again in October 2009. told him the story and he adjusted the cpap to 13cmH20 without any evaluation. He prescribed me nuvigil (150mg), which made me functional at work (previously, I was drinking about 5-6 cups of coffee a day, plus caffeine pills).  -I tried the CPAP again for a month, but tolerated it worse... every time the "ramp" function reach full pressure, I would remove it, even in my sleep.  -Since January 2010, I've been keeping up the exercise, tried numerous diets in 6 week intervals (cycling ketogenic, low/no-carb, 1400cals/day, 2200 cals/day). Every time, I notice I'm the same weight as when I started, though cycling ketogenic worked briefly (12 lbs in 6 weeks) but was torturous. so, since January, I've maintained +/-5lbs pretty much consistently.   -Lethargy and "blackness" (not emotional like depression, but very physical, felt like my body was slowly shutting down) increased. Also noticed a shift in the perception of my tiredness... less physical "sleepiness" where I could fall asleep anywhere, and more of a pervasive mental fatigue.   -Starting in March 2010, I began seeing a bunch of new dr's because my primary gave me overly simplistic advice: "do more cardio, eat better". I saw: internal medicine, ENT, sleep, and nutritionist: -Sleep doc and internal medicine both said that the apnea starved my brain of oxygen, which it interpreted as starvation, so it stored everything as fat, making it extremely hard to lose weight beyond just the motivatioanl aspects of being tired all the time. -Nutritionist was amazed at how much I knew of nutrition and didn't really have any suggestions, other than to deal with apnea first, though she suggested the HMR program.  -ENT thought it was completely weight related. prescribed flonase for my nasal congestion.  -Sleep doc gave me a full face cpap mask (previous was nose only), ambien (10mg) and suggested I try the cpap again until a sleep study could see if there was something else they could do to make cpap tolerable. the goal would be to use it to get back to where I could lose weight. If that didn't work, surgery might be an option (MMA)  -I tried the cpap again for the last 6 weeks (with new mask), but the first 4.5 weeks I couldn't tolerate it... as soon as the full 13cm would kick in, I'd take the mask off (even with the ambien). My wife reported that after the cpap she heard me choke/gasp (apnea event) every minute or two  -Just a week and a half ago, I downloaded the clinician's manual for my cpap machine and I adjusted the pressure down to 8cmH2O. for the first time ever, I was able to keep it on overnight. I used the custom pressure adjustment to increment to 8.2 then 8.4, and I've been using it every night with 8.4 for the past week. At first I felt like a new person, but I feel more physically tired recently, though more lucid. I haven't noticed any difference in weight, but it has only been a week.   -Last monday (after only 3 nights of using the cpap), it was finally time for my split night polysomnography and titration. Something felt weird though and i woke up with my throat feeling abnormally dry and tight. normally I can get my throat tissues to collapse to simulate apnea when I try to explain it to be people, but when I woke up during the study I couldn't. I didn't reach the criteria for the titration portion (which is only 20 events/hr), and I felt very refreshed despite 6 hours of sleep. I went back home at 6am and slept for another 3 hours (sans cpap) and felt completely exhausted again, so I doubt this study will tell me anything though I wish I knew what made things different. The room was quite a bit colder, but that was it.   -this morning, I had my metabolism measured by respirometry. After 10 minutes sitting quietly reading, I breathed into the repirometer for a bit and got a reading of 2410 cals/day with a vO2 of 380. With normal activity but not exercise, the lady administering it said that should give me a normal metabolic rate (ie not just sitting still) of ~3000cals/day. This shocked me since I have not been eating anywhere near that, and with the calories i've been averaging, I should be losing weight even if I just sit in one place all day.   -I had several blood tests over the last year. see below for the results.  -two other peculiar observations I've had recently: -I've had bouts of intense gas pain and bloating. It's been more frequent recently. It partially matches descriptions for "trapped wind". I can't isolate what causes it... thought it was fiber, then dairy, then my protein powder, but it seems kind of random. I've noticed a change in my stools too... I used to have larger more solid movements, but recently, I've had more times when I felt like I had to go, but sat on the toilet only to release gas and more of "greasy" small bits or more explosive. (sorry if that's gross, but I figure more info is better than less). Sometimes extensive 'flatus' is accompanied by a greasy/oily substance that I don't know what it is. - a year or two ago when I lost the 50 lbs, I packed on muscle like crazy. Recently, despite doing my weightlifting alongside a bodybuilder friend, I don't feel muscle or strength gains at anywhere near the same rate (if at all) even if I push as hard as I can during a workout. In fact, I barely notice any gains at all, almost like my body isn't repairing my muscles to be stronger than they were, just the same.   My questions: -why can't I lose weight? do I just need to wait longer with using the cpap? am I not getting enough calories given my muscle mass and RMR? -If I do the HMR "at-home" diet (1200cals/day) will it help? is that too few calories? -Could this have anything to do with the intestinal issues? What can I do to address those? -is there any merit to the idea that apnea makes it hard to lose weight? -are there any other things I haven't thought of? I've felt so crappy from the apnea that I forgot what it feels like to feel good, so I think i tend to group things into "oh it's the apnea.   Thanks so much for helping me! It's been such a frustrating journey. title: high cholersterol
content: I have had relatively high cholersterol all my life -- presently 302.  I exercise daily -- walk 1-2 miles and bicycle 3 miles -- and eat healthy (mostly fruits and vegetables, some meat and starch, ande seldom a dessert).  I don't smoke, weigh 145 lb (5ft 7in) and still run, easily.  My average blood pressure is 100 / 65, and was able to get it up to 128 / 82 only after bicycling hard and running into Walmart to measure it.  Although my doctor recomments I take cholesterol medication, I REALLY don't want to.  Is it possible to live a long life -- over 100 years -- with cholesterol levels around 300?  I am 65.
posted_time: Post  by healthyguy » Sat Aug 07, 2010 10:23 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: high cholersterol
content: Hello, There are different types of cholesterol.  The HDL is considered "good" cholesterol and sometimes it is important to see which of yours is high because some amount of high total cholestrol will be balanced by a high level of the good kind.    There are multiple factors that come into play here.  A big one is genetics and some people are healthy with higher cholesterol.  We don't know why this is the case when it is typically a bad omen for a healthy heart.    Each person is unique and while we look at the majority in predicting mortality and morbidity there are always exceptions.  Nobody can accurately predict your life span.  I would continue doing what you are doing to be sure you are not adding to the genetic predisposition you may have.  Good luck.  Best wishes.

author: salamashka  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Aug 03, 2010 1:35 pm Gender: Male
title: 40 Day Fast
content: I am doing a 40 day fast for religious purposes and health as well. I am on day 15 right now. What should I expect for the next 25 days?
posted_time: Post  by salamashka » Tue Aug 03, 2010 1:50 pm

author: Faye Lang, RN, MSW  Nurse Posts: 468 Joined: Thu Oct 30, 2008 7:01 pm Gender: Female Location: California
title: Re: 40 Day Fast
content: Hello salamashka,  Glucose is the primary fuel in the human body.  When the body doesn't receive intake of food providing glucose for more than 4 to 8 houors, the body relies on the liver to convert glycogen, or stored glucose, to glucose for fuel to support life.  Along with this, the body also uses small amounts of protein to supplement the fuel.  The glycogen may last for up to 12 hours; after that, the body uses glycogen that is stored in muscles, which will last for a few more days.  If glucose is still not provided, the body temporarily uses fat as the fuel source, by converting it into ketone, which is used by the brain as a fuel source.  When fat levels are low (less than 7% of body fat in males, or 10% in females), the body signals distress by an increased urge for food.  Taking medications during this time may have dangerous effects.  If fasting persists, starvation begins to occur, as the body uses protein for fuel.  Muscle wasting occurs, with continued weight loss.  Medical complications of fast-induced starvation include electrolyte imbalances, thinning hair, lanugo (fine, downy hair over the skin), cardiac arrhythmias, and kidney failure.  Death can occur if fasting is continued to complete starvation.  A complete fast, or abstinence of all food and liquids, can hasten starvation and the complications of starvation.  Delerium may occur.  The time to complete starvation will be influenced by the body weight prior to beginning the fast.  While I respect your religious convictions, I must point out that a 40-day fast has considerable health risks.  Good luck to you.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Herbal teas with senna leaf and buchu and breastfeeding?
content: Hello, The herbal supplements, teas, etc. are not monitored by the FDA and testing is never done on pregnant or breastfeeding women so these substances are used with caution because we just can't say for sure, though I expect they would not have adverse effects - there really are not many things that cause problems for babies who are breastfed but the warnings are due to the fact there is little data to support safety.  I would not think it necessary to pump and dump if you are only planning this for a short duration of use but I can't advise you absolutely.  Best wishes.

title: Re: weight gain
content: Hello, It is best to avoid or at least limit saturated and trans fats in your diet to prevent coronary artery disease. title: food allergiess???
content: I am a 30 yr old femail. I have a potential allergy problem.  Back in Jan '05 I went through Rast (blood test) allergy testing for several foods and environmental offenders.  All results were negative.  Later that year in September and October, I went through skin prick allergy testing for the same types of things.  I had all negative results.  In the fall of '06 I had repeat skin testing for nuts and various foods (most of which I had been tested before previously with negative results).  I became pregnant in December and I started to have more prominent type symptoms often times after eating.  I would get really jittery at times, sometimes my mouth or lips would itch, sometimes I would get an upset stomach, and sometimes I felt like my throat was tight, although there was no indication of swelling.  I never broke out into hives or wheezed.  Because of these symptoms, my doc performed another RAST (skin testing was out due to pregnancy) for various foods and environmental agents.  This time, the test did yield positive results, although primarily low.  I tested positive to tomato, green bean, and carrot; all Class I.  There was also potential for corn and potato, although it was "unequivocal."  I also tested positive to Peanuts (class I) and Almonds (class II) along with Timothy grass (Class II) and Ragweed (class I).  Again, most of the numbers were very low and the doc was unsure about "true"  allergies.  He suggested avoidance for about a month or so and see how I feel.  I have been doing that, but still suffering some of the same symptoms.  But now I am a nervous wreck when it comes to eating.  I've researched and consulted others and the consensus seems to be that because my past RAST and skin testing was negative, the most recent test is likely not valid with a positive reaction.  I'm pregnant and concerned about nutrition and now when I eat, I just worry, wondering if I've consumed something bad  and now I'm hypersensitive to any body sensations.  I was allergic to milk as an infant, but other than that, I've had no problems with any other allergies my whole life.   What is your opinion of this situation?  Any input would be appreciated.  Thank you for your time.

author: htlaeh  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Thu Feb 08, 2007 3:51 pm Location: Georgia
title: [no title]
content: The first thing you should do is to begin keeping a food journal or diary. Write down what you eat; including the amount of food you eat; what time you eat and how the food is prepared. You should also list any symptoms that occur and exactly what time the symptoms occur. This food journal will give you and your physician insight concerning what, if any, food is causing your symptoms. Your health care provider may use your food journal in their diagnosis. Speak with your physician and/or a registered dietician concerning your journal and the possibility of going on an Elimination Diet. Do not attempt an Elimination Diet on your own due to the possibility of nutritional deficits.  Concerning the tests used to determiine if you had food allergies: The RAST is used to test for antibodies to specific allergens.  Normal negative results indicate that you probably do not have a “true allergy”; however, the results of the RAST must always be interpreted and used with caution and the advice of your doctor. Even if your RAST test is negative, there is still a small chance that you do have an allergy.  Note that food allergy is an abnormal response that is triggered by the immune system. It is highly likely that you may have food intolerance, which is more common than food allergy. The immune system does not cause food intolerance even though the symptoms may be similar to the symptoms found with allergies.  There can be many types of food intolerance. However, the most common are intolerance to:  Lactose (cow’s milk and other dairy products) Tyrosine Preservatives  Artificial colors Tomato Gluten Corn Nuts Eggs Seafood Wheat Flour Chocolate  There is no reliable blood test or skin test that can confirm food intolerance. If you do have food intolerance, remember that it is very unpleasant but rarely dangerous.  You can immediately begin reading food labels and avoid the following: Artificial sweeteners, MSG, Hydrogenated oils or “trans fat”, Sodium Nitrite, Sulfites or genetically modified foods. Also, eat fresh organic foods in place of processed foods.  Remember, to consult with your physician and/or dietician regarding the results of your food diary.

title: Phentermine and Wellbutrin
content: I am a 51 yr. female with hypothroidism and mild depression.  I take thyroid medication and Wellbutrin SR daily.  I am trying desperately to lose weight, with no success.  I exercise every day and stick to a healthy diet, approximately 1200-1500 calories a day.  My question is this.  I have taken in the past, Phentermine, with great results.  I have an appointment with my doctor soon and I wish to take Phentermine again so that I can stick to an 800 calorie diet to lose this weight.  Is it safe to take Phentermine and Wellbutrin SR at the same time?
posted_time: Post  by linsen » Sat Mar 28, 2009 10:05 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Phentermine and Wellbutrin
content: Hello, It is not recommended that you take these two drugs together unless your doctor deems benefits to outweigh risks and monitors you very closely during a short-term period.  It should not be undertaken casually because of the similarity of action between the drugs and what could amount to an exacerbation of negative side effects.  Also, you should be getting some of the same results with the Wellbutrin that you would get from the phentermine so it is considered  Other weight loss efforts would be recommended.  You might do better with another type of weight loss drug such as sibutramine (Meridia), but it is important for you to discuss anything like this with your doctor since therapeutic duplication would be going on.  Wellbutrin SR itself has been shown to decrease appetite in many people, so adding another would not necessarily improve your situation.  A good eating and exercise program is essential for long-term success in weight loss.  It sounds like you are doing well in that way.  Weight Watchers and other programs have a proven success record but they require diligence over the long term.  Medication treatment typically only lasts for the duration of the treatment, which is not intended to be long-term, and rebound weight gain is the most likely result.  If you can meet with a dietician to create a good program and possibly join a gym with trainers to advise you, your goals can be met and you will be more likely to sustain the healthy changes.  Good luck.

author: sherri629  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Dec 04, 2009 10:11 am Gender: Female
title: ice cream intolerant
content: Hi, I have a strange situation.  Every time i eat ice cream, I get a very bad stomache.  I can drink milk, eat cheese and eat cottage cheese just fine.  I know the simple solution is to not eat ice cream :)  But I would really like to know why this is. I've asked several doctors, but the standard answer is "well that's weird" and they drop it.  Any ideas?
posted_time: Post  by sherri629 » Fri Dec 04, 2009 10:16 am

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: ice cream intolerant
content: Hi, Commercial ice cream is prepared from a number of ingrediants such as   - butterfat,  - nonfat milk solids, - flavoring agents.  - stabilizers,& - sugar  Butterfat imparts its creamy flavor and texture. Butterfat gives ice cream its creamy consistency and texture. The nonfat milk solids make it smooth. Sugar and assorted flavoring agents provide sweetness and add to the ultimate taste. The stabilizers (gum /gelatin) , give the blend a smooth texture by preventing larger ice crystals  forming during the freezing.   Natural flavorings (whole/chopped fruits or nuts), may be added to add variety to texture.Some nuts (esp; the tree nuts such as wall nut, cashew nut) may be contaminated by a fungus(aspergillus spp).  Some icecreams may contain unknown ingredients which may be trade secrets.  Thus, if one is allergic to icecream, it could be allergy to any of the ingredients mentioned above. Best wishes!
posted_time: Post  by Dr.M.Aroon kamath » Sat Dec 26, 2009 9:08 am

title: Re: pre-mature grey hair
content: Hello,Canities ie premature greying of hair can be a genetic trait and need not exactly correlate to the age in which it began for your parents.It also can be caused by an isolated autosomal dominat trait.Medical conditions like pernicious anaemia,thyroid problems,auto immune or immune deficiency states,and drugs like chloroquin could cause canities.You can get a blood count done to rule out anaemias.Oral calcium pantothenate has been effective in few patients but you should get them prescribed by your doctor.There are not many treatments available for premature greying.Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: How long does alcohol stay in urine
content: Hello, Various factors enter into this equation.  Your size is one of those.  In a 150 pound person, the body rids itself of about half an ounce per hour.  This equates to 12 ounces of beer or one can, 4 ounces of wine (typical glass) or one ounce (one shot) of hard liquor.  So, how long it shows up depends on how much you have had to drink.  Best wishes

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: How Much Alcohol is Too Much Alcohol to Consume Regularly
content: Hello, It is believed that some people are predisposed to problems with alcohol and so far we have not found a way to predict those individuals.  Because of this, it is impossible say what amount is safe over the long run.  While a regular drink may be fine for one person, another may become an alcoholic.  But, don't let your sense of not being addicted be your guide.  Most alcoholics believe they are not addicted and that they could quit at any time.  The only sure thing is to avoid alcohol or use it in moderation.  Best wishes.

title: Re: Healthy BMI but exceeding GDA for sat fat
content: Hello, This problem is not just restricted to the overweight.  Normal weight individuals can suffer from the effects of saturated and trans fats. content: Hello, The reason it is an illegal substance is because it does do harm. title: i hate eating.
content: I don't know, just from the title it may sound weird, but it's true, I hate eating.  I do eat, but I have a passionate hatred towards it. I refuse to eat if I'm depressed or overly stressed out, and last year I only ate on the weekends, maybe had a cracker during the week, but that was it. I don't know exactly why that is, I think maybe there's a reason for it, but I have no idea what it could be. I researched about different eating disorders, but I don't really fall into any of the ones I read about like anorexia or bulemia or binge eating. I especially hate eating in public or when people are around, I don't even know why that is, and lately it's been getting worse that I don't want to eat in front of my family (obviously, I live with my family). Things at home have been going terribly for the past month, so maybe it's because I'm depressed that I don't want to eat in front of them?? But what stumps me is that even the word "eat" or "food" makes my stomach turn (not literally, but it just makes me hate food even more) I don't even know how to explain it. I have an extremely long health history which includes Neuroblastoma cancer, twice, so I did have about eight different kinds of chemotherapy that have messed me up in numerous different ways, but this isn't really "normal" for me- per se, and I don't think that any of my treatment would be causing this. About four years ago I had no problem, but since then I just don't. Nothing really happened four years ago, just depression, but it wasn't related to weight or anything really. When I actually do eat though it's always very healthy (I'm a vegetarian), but still I don't even like eating healthy food even though I know it's healthy and won't cause me to gain weight. I do have a bit of a self-conscious weight issue, but I don't know, I don't really believe that could be the cause my dislike towards food.  Anyways, I rambled, what could it be? What do I do?

author: Vinita  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Jan 12, 2009 2:27 pm Gender: Female
title: Natural breast enhancement
content: Hi,  I am 26 yrs old.My weight is 110 pounds and my height is 162cm.My breast is small and I would like to have it increased naturally. I read about herbal supplements like fenugreeks capsules.Will it really work for me? I am also trying to gain weight. Please advice me.
posted_time: Post  by Vinita » Mon Jan 12, 2009 2:38 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Natural breast enhancement
content: Hello, There are no known, proven breast enhancers aside from surgical implantation.  Fenugreek is a supplement commonly used to increase milk production in a lactating woman but I have heard no evidence that it enhances breast size aside from that possibility with the increasing amounts of milk the woman makes.    Most products touted as "natural breast enhancers" whether pills, creams, lotions or potions are scam attempts.    Overall weight gain efforts you can do would be to improve your intake of healthy foods and good fats (avocado, olive oil, fatty fish).  You don't want to damage your health by adding lots of unhealthy calories, refined sugars and saturated or hydrogenated/trans fats.  You could add some more dairy to your diet - ice cream, puddings, cheese can add to your calcium and bone health while adding calories.  Whole grains are healthier for adding carbohydrate calories.  You may want to meet with a nutritionist for a diet program that would be healthy and allow you optimal weight gain in a healthy way.    It is important for you to become comfortable with your body.  Larger breast size may be desirable to some people, but being small has some advantages too.  You might also be surprised to learn that, contrary to media hype, many men find small breasts very attractive.  So much of this is genetic, there is not much to change it.  But, when the time comes to breastfeed a baby, the size will increase naturally and the benefits and enjoyment that comes from this act will more than compensate one day.  If you choose to do surgical enhancement, you could interfere with this natural and amazing opportunity so think seriously before you make such a decision.  Some women are successful even after surgery but sometimes this is compromised.  Breast feeding is a wonderful experience worth protecting.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Jan 13, 2009 12:52 pm

content: There are indeed advantages and disadvantages of having small and big breasts. It's better to love your body and be confident with it. Enhancing it surgically, I believe is the only option or if you are lactating. DDS Austin Dentists Amarillo

author: iris_babe21  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Wed May 20, 2009 7:47 pm Gender: Female
title: weighing error
content: i am a student nurse working in the emergency department. i weighed a patient and in a hurry, miscalibrated the physician weighing scale. what are the implications of these with regard to patient health and nursing plan?
posted_time: Post  by iris_babe21 » Wed May 20, 2009 7:51 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: weighing error
content: Hello First of all, I hope you are able in such a case to share your mistake with someone to correct it in the patient chart.  Everyone makes mistakes at times and the chances of correcting any problem is much greater if you catch it early.  It would mostly depend on how much the scale was off and what kind of condition the patient had.  If it is something where close monitoring of fluid retention is indicated there would likely be daily weights taken and the pattern would be more significant than the single unusual number.  That would most likely stick out as a fluke or error (and as I said, there isn't a nurse out there who has never made one).    Many conditions would not be affected at all but some medications may be calculated based on weight and again, it would depend on how much difference there was and what medication, but most adult doses are similar and would be prescribed on the adult dose vs the size ratio.    Try not to be too hard on yourself.  This is not likely any kind of life and death matter.  Learn from the mistake and help others to learn by sharing.  If it happens to you it can happen to others.  So, if you see a process in the hospital that appears to be a likely cause of future errors, bring it to the attention of supervisors or hospital quality assurance committees.  Nobody wants to make an error that would cause harm to the patient he or she is trying to help.    I hope this helps.  Good luck with your future.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Weight problems
content: Hello, There really aren't any magic weight loss pills, potions or powders out there.  They sell well because so many people struggle as you do but if they were working so well, we would be seeing some dramatic success and not just in the ads.  The teenager at the Y may be able to help.  If he has learned a bit about nutrition, exercise and metabolism, he might have good advice.  Don't assume that his age would automatically preclude his abilities.    In addition, I would recommend seeing a dietician, like a diabetic patient would.  Insurance doesn't usually cover this but it would be money well-spent.  There are reputable weight loss programs out there.  Weight Watchers is one example.    Our sedentary lifestyle has definitely contributed to this universal problem so finding as many ways as possible to get more active can help.  In days past we were likely to be doing physical, manual labor (both men and women).  Now we are more apt to labor mentally and this is disaster for the body.  Thus, we need to get out and plan exercise rather than having it come as a side effect of the work we do otherwise.  This of course means extra time in an already overtaxed schedule.  It is a matter of priorities.  At some point we need to take responsibility for the condition and do something about it.  Maybe multiple channels would help - add a sports activity (hit a tennis ball, swim, ride a bike), take a daily walk either on a lunch hour or before/after work.  A brisk 30 minute walk can do a lot of good, especially in conjunction with other activities and exercise.  Then maybe consider taking a weekly class - Yoga, aerobics, water aerobics, dancing, skating, etc.   Sit on an exercise ball at your desk.  Vary your routine and find something that really interests you so you won't lose interest.  The bottom line is, the acai berry or other supplements will do little if anything if you don't alter your diet and activity.  As for interactions, it is hard to advise since the FDA does not regulate supplements.  They vary greatly in amount of ingredient used, active and inert, and they are not tested as other drugs are.  Without such scientific testing we don't always know what potential interactions might exist.  I would recommend asking your pharmacist for detailed printouts of the medications you are taking to see if any of them indicate a concern with herbal products.  As I said though, this may not show up because of the loose regulation of these items.  Good luck and congratulations on your desire to get control or your weight and health.  It is true that slow, steady progress will ultimately pay off so patience is a virtue here.  Best wishes.

author: guy28  Guest Posts: 10 Joined: Sat Nov 17, 2007 11:09 am
title: Premature Aging Please Help
content: I recently turned 30, and until about 2 moths ago have never had any problems in this area. But within that time I've begun finding gray hair in my beard and on my head, also on both arms and legs. As well as hair loss in the shower. Neither of my parents are gray or thinning. What would be causing my hair, even my body hair to be turning gray all of a sudden like this? Could it be a reversible health issue?
posted_time: Post  by guy28 » Tue Jun 02, 2009 3:09 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Premature Aging Please Help
content: Hello,  First let me assure you that graying and thinning hair does not mean your body is aging faster than it should and it would not be considered premature aging.  It is a skin/hair/follicle/hormone condition with strong hereditary causes.  Other bodily functions normally affected by the aging process will not accompany this premature hair condition.    There are some health problems that can cause hair loss such as thyroid disorders, vitamin B12 deficiencies, poor nutrition, anemia, and other hormone problems, so a good physical exam with lab work would be recommended to rule out such things.  There are treatments that can help slow the hair loss even in the absence of a health condition, such as Finasteride (Propecia) and Minoxidil (Rogaine).  These don't work in every case but they do help some.  The process can often be slowed if it is started early enough so you should not hesitate to see your doctor - ideally a dermatologist.    Stress hormones can also contribute to hair graying as well as hair loss so consider your mental state as well as your physical health.  Genetics is a funny thing - you can get genes for traits that make you different from your parents.  You may have had a grandparent with similar characteristics.  Many men at least have spots of baldness in their 20s and the pattern of the parents often follows but not necessarily.  You get 2 pairs of every gene (one from each parent) You would have gotten it from your mother, because it travels on the X chromosome (supplied by the mother) and you get only one X chromosome.  If your mother happened to have inherited the gene for baldness, you could also have it with no dominant gene to overcome it (because you only have one X).  I hope this simplified explanation makes sense.  Whatever you do, don't be fooled by commercial websites and advertisements for products that are not approved by the FDA but that promise magic cures.  The American Hair Loss Association only recommends a few methods and as much as they would like to find a product that could prevent the heartache that comes to people who suffer from this disease, they have not endorsed any others besides those mentioned above along with some surgical treatments.    There may be some safe herbal remedies but these should not make extravagant claims or cost exorbitant amounts of money.  The "snake oils" on the other hand, likely will do both.  I know it is disheartening to think the you may look older than your years but many young men's  prematurely white hair becomes a symbol and is very attractive.  Examples include Bill Clinton, Steve Martin and Phil Donahue.  According to US magazine, many celebrities are almost totally gray.  As an old TV commercial says, "only their hairdresser knows for sure."  If it is too distressing to go naturally gray, in spite of the "distinguished" look that often goes with it, you can do as women have for years - dye it.  Start with a color just a shade lighter than your natural and use only semi-permanent color.  Short hair almost always looks better for gray hair.  You might invest in a trip to a good stylist/colorist to advise you before you jump into something that might make you want to put on a hat.  The truth is, early graying is a bit trendy now so if you find it's just the luck of the draw, you may want to wear it with pride.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Thu Jul 02, 2009 12:33 am

Lost 5 lbs last August on WW.  I am retaining water as well.  My doctor tested me for thyroid issues and then just said that was all she could think of.  I know my diet is a good one - about 1200 cals a day, low fat - lots of fruit, whole grain (brown rice, etc), snacks are nuts, dark chocolate etc.  I have not lost one pound since starting my diet 3 months ago.  I have also done a 2 week colon cleanse (nothing crazy just a slow natural one) and tried 2 weeks of water pills (Ok'd by my doc).  Nothing....  I'm very concerned that something is wrong with me - glucose normal, a little high, other blood tests OK except a slightly elevated bilrubin which doc said is OK.  What type of doctor or test should I be asking for?  Someone recommended an abdominal scan - perhaps liver/kidney issues?  My stomach is very bloated, usually not like this.  No real digestion issues - bowel movements normal, regular.  I really feel that something is going on and don't want to just be told to keep dieting, etc. I want to rule out any other issues.  I would so appreciate any assistance - ideas - etc.  Thank you!
posted_time: Post  by mexigrl » Fri May 22, 2009 10:45 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Medical Reasons for Inability to Lose Weight
content: Hello, Physically thyroid is the most likely culprit.  If that is normal, you really do have little control here except to continue to stay the course.  Sometimes we reach a plateau but if we stay with the program, eventually we break through.  Try to be patient during this time.  Your metabolism may be trying to keep you at a comfortable weight your body is used to.  I would recommend a high protein/low carb diet to see if such an alteration helps.  Increasing your physical activity is also good, even though you are making good progress on that end right now.    Since your doctor has checked your thyroid it seems unlikely it is a physical problem.  Perhaps seeing a counselor will help you to deal with your difficulties and meeting with a dietician might be helpful as well.  Sometimes we consume hidden calories that add weight faster than we can lose it so being strict with a food journal can help you to analyze  your intake and evaluate it better.  Your goals are commendable for helping you to become healthier.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by iforget123 » Sat May 30, 2009 9:04 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Gaining weight.
content: Hello, I would not recommend steroids because of the potential for serious negative side effects that go along with them.  Many different body organs can be affected and permanent damage can occur.  Much of our metabolism is due to genetics and there is little that can be done to overcome your natural body makeup.  Just as some people find it almost impossible to lose weight; others are challenged by the opposite problem which can actually be more difficult to change.    I would recommend continuing good overall nutrition.  Be sure to take a good vitamin and mineral combination along with perhaps protein supplements containing certain amino acid combinations such as creatnine and glutamine.  If you haven't had a complete physical exam recently it is always a good idea to be sure there is no underlying problem that is causing the problem.  Chances are there is no problem other than your own body type but any progress you make will be slow so patience is important.  You cannot expect fast results.  Try weight lifting to help build muscle mass and stay with the program.    Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by merykate » Thu Apr 30, 2009 5:48 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: underweight breastfeeding
content: Hello, Fortunately even underweight women can successfully breastfeed without harming the baby.  Everyone's metabolic rate is unique to them and you obviously burn calories easily.  Breast feeding does take some of those calories - around 500/day.  The important thing is that you are eating a healthy diet and meeting your requirement for calories and nutrients; not whether or not your weight is average.  It has been shown that even women who are in starvation can feed their infants.  Their own nutritional status may result in some bone loss and a loss of any fat stores, but the baby usually does fine.  It's one of those miracles of motherhood.    As long as you are making good food choices, I would not worry about what the scale says and recognize this is your body and the way it responds to energy input and exertion.  Of course it is wise to monitor your baby for weight gain and around six months you can add some solids to your baby's diet with cereal, then vegetables and fruit.  Continuing to breastfeed is recommended and will help your baby to be healthy in ways no formula can imitate.  Congratulations on your desire to give your baby the best.  Take care and good luck,

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: can i lose 5 lbs a week?
content: Hello, It is possible to do this though evidence shows a slower, steady weight loss is more prone to be long-lasting.  If  you were to have weight loss surgery you could lose 1.5 - 2 lbs. per day and still be healthy but your body would be in a state of controlled starvation so when undertaking such a drastic effort you should definitely take a multivitamin and eat the right kinds of foods with extra protein; not just starve yourself to death which sometimes results in rebound weight gain as your body adjusts to the extreme cut in calories.  Your body conserves, detecting starvation.    If you do this under medical supervision there is a good chance you can do it without harm to  yourself.  It is a hard goal you are setting for yourself however.  Best wishes.

author: steponmi  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu May 21, 2009 5:37 pm Gender: Female
title: How do i get my 102 yr old aunt to exercise more?
content: My aunt is 102, and in ok health.  She spends most of her day in a wheel chair even though we try to get her out of it. She hates walking.  How do I make working out fun and not too hard on her.  I know we probably don't have her for very much longer but I don't want to see her go out not fighting to keep all her motor skills.
posted_time: Post  by steponmi » Thu May 21, 2009 5:44 pm

author: Faye Lang, RN, MSW  Nurse Posts: 468 Joined: Thu Oct 30, 2008 7:01 pm Gender: Female Location: California
title: Re: How do i get my 102 yr old aunt to exercise more?
content: Hello steponmi,  When in the wheelchair, does your aunt "walk" using her feet to get around?  If she does, she's getting adequate exercise of her lower extremities.  If she doesn't, then first ask her why she doesn't like to walk.  Does she have a cane or walker? Does she feel dizzy or unsteady?  Does it cause pain anywhere?  Does she figure that at 102, she can pretty much decide how much activity she wants?  See if she'll exercise in her wheelchair, by moving her legs by doing heel/toe heel/toe pedaling with her feet.  Will she kick a ball?  Before she gets out of bed, you could assist her in doing strengthening exercises, as pushing against your hand with each foot, while you put pressure against it.  She could do kicks while lying on her back.  If she simply will not cooperate with your ideas, there's really not much you can do about it, and perhaps not much you SHOULD do about it.  She knows best how she feels.  Good luck to both of you.  I hope she is able to see the benefits of exercise.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: anorexic/bulimic daughter ,with stomach pains
content: Hello, Thanks for writing in.  Anorexia is a complex problem which involves physical, psychological, and spiritual factors.    Certainly, the stomach cramping with diarrhea could be from a viral gastrointestinal bug which should resolve within seven days.  Maintaining hydration is important.  And watch for fever which may indicate infectious diarrhea.  Also, with the anorexia/bulimia, consider the amount of food she is taking in.  With decreased food intake or forced vomiting, the stomach and intestines may spasm.  And of course laxative abuse is common and can cause GI symptoms.   Another consideration is her menustrual cycle - which can cause abdominal cramping.  However, if she is very thin, she may have stopped menstruating.  A multidisciplinary team is important and should include family practice physician, gastroenterologist, dietician, and counselor.  Take care and keep us posted.

title: Anorexia Recovery
content: I developed an eating disorder, anorexia, approximately 3 years ago. I was anorexic for a year before receiving treatment. content: I'm 19 years old, 20 in March, and have excellent cholesterol levels and blood pressure. I have slight bradycardia, but am overall in great health in that perspective. According to my BMI, however, I am obese. I weigh roughly 180, and have been told I should, ideally, weigh just over 130. Am I unhealthy?
posted_time: Post  by Miranna » Fri Jan 09, 2009 4:11 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: 19 yo female- Healthy BP, HR, Chol.- BMI~31- Healthy?
content: Hello, It is well known that excess weight can cause long-term health problems.  A BMI of 31 is not a good place to be.  There are many areas you may now be healthy, as evidenced by the blood work and blood pressure, but you are at risk for types of cancer, diabetes, pregnancy complications and future high blood pressure or cholesterol that can cause eventual damage.    I would recommend seeing a nutritionist or joining an organization to help you achieve some healthy weight loss goals.  Best wishes and good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: advice on eph 25
content: Hello, The FDA has been warning against the use of Ephedra for weight loss since 2003.   They can cause serious health concerns, especially in combination with vigorous exercise and/or in combination with other stimulants such as caffeine.    I understand you are frustrated, but there is no magic pill, potion or powder proven to be effective, especially in the absence of a low calorie, high energy-output eating and exercise plan.  There are some aids that may help to a limited degree but they are not going to do the job for you and the results will probably be disappointing if you are expecting miracles.   Phentermine works for some people but is intended for short-term use only.  Some SSRI antidepressants also cause a decreased appetite for some people.  You should discuss your concerns with your health care provider.  There is also a medication called Meridia (sibutramine) that helps and is available by prescription.  It sometimes raises blood pressure so you may not be a candidate if yours is elevated.  This medication is thought to affect your body as an appetite suppressant.  It should not be taken with other SSRI antibiotics since it works on neurotransmitters like they do.  Alli (Orlistat) inhibits the absorption of fat in the intestines.  You should limit your fat consumption to avoid unpleasant side effects (diarrhea).  It is available without prescription but is sanctioned by the FDA as safe.  There are also medically supervised mostly liquid diets that work for many people who need rapid weight loss.  Otherwise the tried and true methods such as Weight Watchers are about the best.    Whatever plan you choose, it can't hurt to take a multivitamin to help supplement your nutrition.  Good luck and congratulations on your desire to improve your health.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: UNEXPLAINED RAPID WEIGHT GAIN
content: Hello, You have not indicated what your BMI is and whether or not your weight loss goals are realistic or idealistic.  Sometimes the body tries to reach equilibrium and needs more weight to sustain health, prepare the body for reproduction and other normal physiological processes.  We may want to be thinner than what our bodies need to be in order to be healthy so we can be fighting a losing battle to lose too much weight.  Of course I don't know if this is the situation with you but without more information, I realize it is possible.    I would have a physical exam with a doctor to determine what your weight loss ideal goals should be.  A dietitian could also advise you on that.  If your mental image of yourself is unrealistic, you may need to talk with a therapist about your body image perception.    Aside from the body's natural efforts to gain weight for health, if it seems you are truly becoming overweight by BMI, you should find out through the physical exam if there are issues with your thyroid.  Underactive thyroid gland can result in weight gain.  Eating healthy food, as you are doing, and avoiding junk food with empty calories is your smartest effort.  Congratulations on your physical activity.  Best wishes.

title: Can you permanently damage your metabolism?
content: Ok, I’ll give some background info.  I’ve battled my weight since I was about 16.  When I was younger, I used to ride my bike & run A LOT.  Over the years I have always used dexatrim because my appetite always seemed to be so out of control.  Now that it’s off the market, I went to the extreme of getting phentermine online (my regular physician does NOT know).  I did this for three years & it worked wonderfully until my tolerance built up so much I would have to take four at a time…at that point I could not afford it anymore & realized that it had become a problem for me.  So, during those years, I wouldn’t eat all day (because I wasn’t hungry) but I always ate at night.  I’ve been dieting and exercising for the last 2 years with no results and a steady climb in my weight.  At that point, I decided I wanted to do it the right way and not rely on pills, etc.  I’m wondering if my metabolism is completely shot?  I’m 32 years old so I know that a female’s metabolism decreases as we age.  I’ve totally overhauled my diet over the last three years, switching out white bread for wheat breads, eating tons of fruits and veggies, etc., etc.  My thyroid was check last year and everything was fine.  I know my body is VERY SENSITIVE to anything that I do, medicines, exercise (my body adapts VERY fast).  Walking (2 years, 2 times a day) did not do anything for me so in December I started running (20-60 min at least 3 days per week) & working out with the gym equipment for about an hour 3 times per week.  Although it’s only been 3 months, my appetite is out of control, I’ve gained weight & my clothes are fitting even tighter.  Help!!!!  What can I do?  I cannot afford to just accept this and buy a whole new wardrobe, in addition to the fact that now I’m crossing the threshold of being considered “obese” by all the charts I look at.  I also journal what i eat.  The website I use tells me that for my height (5'3) and weight (145) i need only eat 990 calories per day to lose 2 pouds per week.  Am i eating too little and sending myself in starvation mode?  At this point, i am just afraid of food.  I know if I drastically restrict my calories, i will lose.  BUT i desperatly want to do it right this time & be in the best shape of my life & not have to worry about food on a daily basis. Do I just need to wait it out longer & keep doing what I’m doing.  Can you repair a broken metabolism?  I worry that I’ve done irreparable damage by yo-yo dieting and especially the phentermine for 3 years.  I'm very frustrated...maybe some understanding could help me be a little more hopeful & patient.   thank you for any help you can give me.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Can you permanently damage your metabolism?
content: Hi there --  There are a number of things which concern me in your post, not the least of which is the prior  phentermine use, and hope you will inform your doctor of this, perhaps as a "confessional." Your doctor isn't there to judge you,  but to take care of you, and it's important that this information be entered into your medical record. While it (and the other things you've done) won't damage -- or permanently alter your metabolism, phentermine can damage other things. It doesn't sound like it has, but if there were some future problem and no one  knew about your having used it -- to excess for a while,too -- that could be a major clue lost. So think about that,  please.   Now then, the next concern: your height vs. weight: this sounds almost good! According to BMI calculations it is just at the bottom end of "overweight" and  nowhere near "obesity." Nowhere.   You've gone into a crash program intending to lose weight, and you're doing everything right. One of the problems often encountered with this however, at least if done right (as you're doing it) is weight gain early on, due to increased muscle mass. Sometimes this can't be readily overcome, depending on the basic body phenotype you happen to have. At this point, other than the fit of your clothes and what that might cost to accomodate, you really don't need to be overly concerned about your weight. The fact that you seem to be concerns me a great deal,  because as a society we are plagued by a media inundation of skinny-worship.  You sound very healthy and the height-weight ratio, while it could stand some very minor tweaking (very minor) sounds very attractive, actually, so beware of body dysmorphia, the delusion that one is "obese" when in fact everything is just fine (or so close no one could estimate by eyeball alone).   The caloric intake you're considering is pretty minimal, but if -- if! -- it doesn't cause you to feel tired, overly hungry, or fatigued, then it should provide the minimum necessary nutrition. But if you're not enjoying life -- including eating -- and have no true obesity problem, then I hope you'll consider that while the metabolism can be altered through diet and exercise -- among other things -- it does take time, and again, you have to always consider which body phenotype you were born with and just maintain it in good condition while making sure you don't drive yourself crazy trying to meet some artificial "standard." I have to repeat this: you are not currently anywhere near obese. If you were to lose a mere 10 lbs you would be well within the BMI "normal" range. Two pounds per week is also an ambitious goal for someone who is as petite as you are. Not terrible, but a lot to expect, especially if you happen to be an endomorph or mesomorph (two of the more "squared off" body types; the third is ectomorph, which would likely be taller, with longer long bones and naturally more willowy). You probably have a gymnast's body by nature, and that you can't change -- nor should you want to.   I hope I've been able to help you some with all this. It's a lot to take in, I know,and the pressure to be "skinny" verges sometimes on the pathological. It's one of our society's biggest ills. Give yourself a little time and hopefully the small amount you need to lose to be totally Within Normal Limits will also allow your wardrobe to stay where it is. But for goodness' sake, don't let that be your guide. You sound like a very healthy, attractive young woman. I hope you'll continue to take good care of yourself and again, please think about telling your doctor, just for the record, that you did use phentermine for a while. I think you dodged the bullet with that, as you probably couldn't do the exercise program you do now otherwise,  but it still should be in the record. Other than that it sounds like you're doing wonderfully. Keep up the good work and please follow up with us here as needed.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Proper use of Phentermine
content: Hello, It is safe even for a small amount of weight loss.  It is an appetite suppressant and actually works best when used short-term.  It is not intended for long-term use at all.    The biggest concern with this drug comes when it is combined with fenfluramine (fen phen) which has been shown to sometimes increase the risk of heart valve problems.  Best wishes.

title: fasting with hep c
content: Is it ok to go on a fast for 5 days or so if i have hep c? My friend who is a biologist said that it would help the viral load to go down.  I also love to eat sweets like preserves, about 2.5 sandwiches with lots of preserves on it a day. Is it bad for my liver?  I've heard that carrots absorb a lot of radiation and coutious about eating them, is that true?  thank you very much.
posted_time: Post  by kosh33 » Thu Jan 29, 2009 1:22 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: fasting with hep c
content: Hello Kosh33,  Being infected with Hepatitis C would not, in itself, be a contraindication to fasting.  If, however, there was significant damage to the liver to the point where it were failing (end stage liver disease), this could be a contraindication to fasting since the liver helps maintain blood sugar levels.  It is very unlikely that fasting will affect your viral load, though.  A five day fast can have significant health effects so I would not recommend you doing this without consulting with your physician first to be sure it is OK for you.  Regarding the sugar, the main issue here is weight gain.  It is best to have a balanced, healthy diet but having preserves is not necessarily a bad thing as long as there is enough other foods to keep your diet in balance.  I am also not aware of any contraindication to eating carrots.  If one eats too many carrots, though, the carotene in them can deposit in the skin turning the person an orangish color.  Reducing the carrot intake will result in reversal of the coloration.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: weight gain, cholesterol, triglycerides levels increase
content: Hello, I would not expect these results with birth control pills, even the weight gain. Some women report a gain but usually it is only around five pounds and there is much debate about whether or not it is caused by the pill itself.    The amount of estrogen in each of these pills is similar enough that I would not expect a problem that way, though switching to a different brand is always one thing to try when you have side effects.    There are genetic conditions that cause high cholesterol even in people who are not at all overweight and who eat healthy food and exercise regularly.  While these measures (losing weight, eating well and exercising) help prevent high cholesterol and triglycerides, in some people there's more to it so you should have this evaluated by your family doctor, internal medicine specialist or other health care provider.  You may need medication to help lower it.    This problem can be caused by medications but it would not be typical with oral contraceptives so you should not have to discontinue their use.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: stretch marks,no weight change- so why?
content: Hello, Adolescence itself often brings stretch marks because of the body changes that are occurring with rapid growth, even if you haven't had a marked weight increase.  There is also a genetic factor - some people get these and others do not.    Don't overuse any ointments containing hydrocortisone.  You may find you can disguise them a bit with fake tan and in time they fade.  Maintaining a healthy weight and doing toning will help to prevent excessive stretching of the skin in the future too.  I wouldn't expect much bleeding though so it would be wise to have a physical exam and ask your health care provider about it.    I do not recommend any "magic" stretch mark creams - they are costly and mostly ineffective.  It doesn't hurt to moisturize with a rich cream but it needn't be anything specific to stretch marks.  Best wishes.

title: Cadmium Overdose/Poisoning
content: I have reason to beleive that I have high amounts of Cadmium in my system. Is there any way to reduce Cadmium levels in the body?? Is there any way to flush Cadmium from the body??
posted_time: Post  by Quasar » Thu Jan 15, 2009 3:53 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Cadmium Overdose/Poisoning
content: Hello,  According to OSHA (Occupational Safety and Health Administration), acute symptoms of cadmium toxicity include flu like symptoms (fever, chills, headache,muscle aches) or respiratory symptoms (cough, shortness of breath, wheezing) and potential progression to pulmonary edema and asphyxia.   Therefore, if you suspect acute exposure to cadmium go to the emergency department.   OSHA also describes that chronic exposure may lead to cancer (lung and prostate), emphysema, osteoporosis, and proteinuria (kidney disease).  OSHA lists the following work areas as potential hazards: repairing gas meter (cadmium dust) repariring aircraft (cadmium dust) shipyard equipment smelting operations handling of certain batteries, paints, and phosphate fertilizers.  Other sources of cadmimium are tobacco and certain foods (cadmium is absorbed into plants eg grains and vegetables through environmental pollution both air and soil).  Women are at higher risk for cadmium toxicity as iron deficiency increases cadmium absorbtion.  The medical literature reports that attempts to chelate (to bind a substance in order to eliminate it from the body) cadmium does not help and may in fact worsen kidney toxicity.  Treatment is mainly supportive ie treating symptoms for acute exposure and monitoring bone, kidney and lungs for chronic disease.  Vitamin D supplements to prevent osteoporosis.  Avoidance of nephrotoxic medicines and treating comorbid disease to protect the kidney and stopping tobacco use.    Lastly, the best intervention is prevention.  Decreasing environmental pollution, decreased use of phosphate fertilizers, proper handling of industrial materials, and for workers in high risk areas - respirators.
posted_time: Post  by Tom Plamondon PA-C » Sat Jan 17, 2009 10:01 am
