author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Healthy Diet to lower high cholesterol, IBS, Asthma & PCOS
content: . Hello, One of the best diets readily available would be Weight Watchers.  They have proven success and they prescribe healthy eating habits with a variety of foods.    For cholesterol reduction, you should of course also limit hydrogenated fats (often found in mixes, bakery items, etc), saturated fats (often found in fried foods) fatty meats, animal products such as whole milk and eggs  You should also increase the consumption of foods high in fiber (fruit, vegetables, legumes and whole grains like oats). Good fats such as olive oil, fatty fish, nuts, and avocado help lower cholesterol so these should be included in your diet.  As for IBS, each person is different in the way this interferes with life.  Some people find that specific foods cause a bad reaction; others find it is very unpredictable.  You would be wise to avoid or at least limit caffeine, carbonation, coffee (even decaf), high sugar foods, milk products, gas-producing foods such as beans, broccoli and cabbage, sorbitol and xylitol (certain artificial sweeteners which sometimes aggravate diarrhea).  If you eliminate the common offenders, you can try gradually reintroducing a food to see how you, personally, respond.  Add only one new food/week so you can track the effects without confusing it with other foods.    Eat slowly in a relaxed environment.  Drink plenty of water and get regular exercise which promotes good G.I. function.  Try to reduce stress as well.      I don’t know of any dietary measures for general asthma (unless it is triggered by a food allergy) or PCOS.    Good luck with this
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Mon Jan 12, 2009 2:10 pm

author: 150kgwoman  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Jan 04, 2009 1:25 pm Gender: Female
title: Diet Pills Xenical and Duromine
content: I am currently on Xenical and have been for about 26 days.  I have been trying to eat healthy but lately seem to be hungry all the time and have been eating a lot of unhealthy foods like pizzas, burgers and a lot of rice. I want an appetite supressant to help me control my cravings and really help jump start my weight loss and healthy eating once again.  As far as I know I do not have diabetes or high blood pressure or any other ailments or that is because I have not checked.  Is it safe to be taking both Xenical and Duromine together?   Thanks for your advice
posted_time: Post  by 150kgwoman » Sun Jan 04, 2009 1:47 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Diet Pills Xenical and Duromine
content: Hello, The most concerning interactions with Xenical are cyclosporin (antibiotic) and supplements containing vitamins A,D,E, K, beta-carotene and warfarin (blood thinner). I do not have any information on Duromine and can only assume this is a supplement, not regulated by the FDA.  I don't know specifically if this is a problem.  You can also consult with a local pharmacist since there could be other possible interactions not included in this general listing.    On this drug you should also not eat excessive amounts of fat since this will result in diarrhea.  If you eat no fat at a meal, you don't need to take your dose of medication since the action is to interfere with fat absorption.  Your fats should comprise no more than 30% of your caloric intake.  You should take a multivitamin to help compensate for the possible loss of nutrient absorption while taking this medication.    Good luck.

author: Jonny5771  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Jan 05, 2009 9:19 pm Gender: Male
title: Rapid Weight Loss, now i have wrinkles. help please
content: quote"Rapid Weight Loss. If weight loss occurs too rapidly, the volume of fat cells that cushion the face are also decreased before chemicals in the skin can react. This not only makes a person look gaunt, but can cause the skin to sag."  i loss the weight to fast and now i have wrinkles on my face. if i try gaining the weight fast again then lose it slower this time, will that fix the problem?
posted_time: Post  by Jonny5771 » Mon Jan 05, 2009 9:23 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Rapid Weight Loss, now i have wrinkles. help please
content: Hello,  I understand your concern, but NO, that will not help and from a health standpoint this would be a really bad idea to intentionally regain the lost weight.  Even if you lose again, the "yo-yo" effect is bad for you.  Skin stretching that occurs with excessive fat causes the tissue to be sometimes permanently changed.  Sometimes surgery is the only correction and at times it is indicated.  As you age, wrinkles are inevitable so try not to stress too much over this.  Your health is much more important than your appearance so you have done a good thing to lose the excess weight.  Even if you can't remove the wrinkles, this is still a much better situation for you.  Best wishes.

title: Re: Do diet pills interact with Synthroid?
content: Hello, Supplements are not regulated or studied by the FDA so information is limited as to their interaction.  When you know what supplement you will be using you might ask your pharmacist to check for any interactions with Synthroid.  He/she should be able to print a detailed list of things that should not be used with the drug and could explain how serious the interaction might be if the supplement contains any of those.  You can get this list online but you will probably not know how serious the response might be.  You can also discuss it with your prescribing doctor.     If the supplement is mostly vitamins, chances are it will be fine.    Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by lisakristene » Tue Dec 30, 2008 9:36 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Effects of a Dairy Allergy?
content: Hello, Most people do not have an actual allergy but more of a sensitivity to dairy or lactose (milk sugar) intolerance.  I would not expect any damage as a result of using dairy on occasion if you handle it OK.  If you had an allergy to milk, there is always the concern that you could have a serious hypersensitivity reaction so if you notice more than a rash, such as trouble breathing or feeling like your throat is swelling, you should see a doctor right away.  Best wishes.

posted_time: Post  by jussy08 » Fri Sep 12, 2008 5:09 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Weight loss after pregnancy
content: Hello, I am so sorry to hear of your loss.  This is a very hard thing for a mom to bear.    Your weight loss efforts are already headed in the right direction since you are going to the gym.  Physical activity is such an important part of any plan you choose.  There are many that could help guide you.  Weight Watchers is a proven successful and healthy eating plan and they are available on the internet now.  There are also other online support systems such as sparkpeople.com.   These sites guide you about what to eat; what to avoid and can help jump start your efforts with ideas.  The bottom line is you need to expend more energy than you take in from calories, so more activity; less food - particularly empty calories (sugar, candy, soda, refined flour, cake, etc.) and high fat foods such as deep fried anything.  I suspect patience is what you need now.  Keep doing as you are and you will likely succeed in time.  A slow and steady course can be longer-lasting than a quick fix from a fad diet.  Vegetables and fiber must be part of the eating plan.   It has also been shown that an adequate intake of water is important.    Good luck in your efforts to achieve good health.

title: Re: gaining weight, even though i am dieting and exercising!
content: Hello, I know how frustrating this is. author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Trouble Gaining Weight
content: Hello, I know of no vitamin or supplement that will help this problem.  Some people do take nutrient drinks or shakes which are basically high in calories - the old energy in vs energy out idea.  The most important thing you could do would be to eat healthy food so the calories you take in also have nutritional value.  Dairy products are good examples - try to eat more ice cream, pudding, milk, cheese and yogurt.  Working out can sometimes help you build body mass as well and this can help your body image immensely.  You may also benefit from a nutrition consult with a registered dietician.  Some psychological support might also be helpful - perhaps even hypnosis.  Try not to dwell too much on your weight but live a healthy and happy life.  Making heatlhy choices will help down the road in other aspects of your life and health.  If you feel you have some tendency towards anorexia it might also be good to get some psychological counseling.  Good luck.

posted_time: Post  by taytay » Sun Nov 09, 2008 2:14 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: glutin intollerance
content: Hello, Blood tests and sometimes a biopsy of the small intestine can diagnose this inherited disorder.  It is treated by avoiding all gluten in the diet.  The good news is that many products are now available for those with this sensitivity, made from alternate ingredients.    You should avoid breads, cereals, cookies and all other types of foods or other products with wheat, barley or rye, including some beers, lipsticks, postage stamps, medications and vitamins. Some patients cannot tolerate oats either.  You need to see a doctor about this.  Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Why can I not eat anything and keep it down?
content: Hello, It sounds like you have developed some anorexia and it is important to get help.  You probably have been OK so far since you had some extra weight to lose but your body went into starvation mode and you conserve energy and strength when caloric intake is too low.    Your doctor should do a complete physical exam to rule out any underlying endocrine or gastric disorders.  If this is OK, you should see a therapist or psychiatrist who treats eating disorders.  This is confidential so you don't have to discuss it with anyone if you don't want to.   Please see a professional as your electrolytes can be seriously disturbed and your body can fail with resulting serious illness or even death.  Let us know how it goes.    Best wishes.

title: Poor Diet Causing Migraine?
content: Hello,  This past month I decided to do a digestive cleansing by cutting out all added sugar, fats and most oils. I didn't really feel a noticeable change in my body, maybe just less bloated.   This past weekend, however, my diet became very poor (thanks to Halloween and a wedding!). I pretty much binged on lots of sugary and flour-y junk food. Then on Sunday night I started to feel queasy. It wasn't a severe nauseau, it was more like a kind of car sick feeling. Early that Monday morning, I awoke to a violent migraine, which caused the shakes and nausea.   My migraine subsided after taking some Tylenol and sleeping, but I felt queasy all day. I felt fine when I woke up today, but the queasiness has since come back and is still in and out.   I rarely get migraines- they are very isolated and are usually caused by pms or sinus pressure. I am suffering from neither right now. I also tried to think of what I've been eating and found I have added nothing brand new to my diet. I then thought it may have been dehydration because I drank very few liquids this weekend, but I have been replenishing with plenty of herbal teas and fresh water since yesterday morning.   My question is, could this be related to my sudden drastic change in diet, adding sugar and unhealthy fats, or could it be related to something more serious? I wanted to wait an additional day before visiting with my doctor. Otherwise, I feel fine and do not feel like I've contracted a virus.  Thank you for your time.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: trying to lose weight
content: Hello, Being overweight can contribute to these symptoms but 20 lbs. is not what we would consider obese so it may or may not help with your cycle.  You should be evaluated by your gynecologist who may want to treat you with hormones or if you have PCOS (polycystic ovary syndrome) there are other treatments that can be helpful as well.  A good, reliable, and effective eating plan is Weight Watchers.  This is not new, not faddish, but it really works.  It is a healthy eating plan more than a "diet" and many people have been successful using it.  There are other plans of course but this is one of the most readily available that uses normal foods you can prepare yourself.  Their point system makes it easy to calculate when you eat out as well.    Of course exercise is an important part of any weight loss effort, besides being critical for good health overall.  At least try to take a 30 minute walk every day.  Congratulations on your desire to be healthy.  Good luck!

author: Chikeets  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Sep 23, 2008 2:41 pm Gender: Female
title: Cinnamon and Honey tea
content: Hello, I have recently come accross a diet (so to speak) consisting of a mix of cinnamon, honey and water. The claim is that taken half an hour before breakfast and before bed at night it does not allow fat to accumulate in the body. Just wondering if this is in fact true and if it is safe to do while breastfeeding? Thanks.
posted_time: Post  by Chikeets » Tue Sep 23, 2008 2:51 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Cinnamon and Honey tea
content: Hello, This mixture would be perfectly safe while breastfeeding but I am doubtful about the claims.  I know of no such thing that will prevent fat from accumulating in the body.  There is a medication (Orlistat) which blocks the absorption of fat from the diet causing diarrhea in many people so they still must reduce the fat intake, but even this does not block any body accumulation of fat.  This has more to do with extra calories, lack of exercise to burn it off and genetics.  Best wishes.

My weight right now is at 220lbs at 5'7" height.  I am also currently started on Weight Watchers.  Will this weight loss program interfere with the weight loss pills?  Thank you for your time reading and answering my questions.
posted_time: Post  by cookie49 » Sat Sep 20, 2008 12:44 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Diet Pills (Alli - Orlistat 60mg capsules)
content: Hello, The way orlistat works is it blocks absoprtion of fats.  It works best with fewest side effects if you decrease fats from your body.  Because they aren't absorbed they often cause diarrhea as your body gets rid of the undigested fat.  This is the most common side effect.  If you are not willing to reduce fat consumption, you should not expect the pill to do the work for you.  Fats are also involved in gall bladder function.  After eating cholecystokinin release and gallbladder contraction might be decreased, with the possibility of an increased risk of gallstone formation.  So, you could have this problem again but it may be no worse than the risk you already have based on your history of gallstones.  There has not been enough study of this to know for sure.    There is also the possibility it could increase your risk for kidney stones.  You may have to decide for yourself if the risk is worth the benefit.  However, using it in conjunction with following Weight Watchers should not be a problem and will probably be helpful since it is important for you to eat a healthy, well-balanced, low-fat diet. Weight Watchers would accomplish this.  Best wishes and good luck in your goal to lose excess weight.  Don't forget to exercise regularly.

author: albogado  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Aug 28, 2008 8:53 am Gender: Female
title: Stiffness and pain that travels
content: I am 31 years old, healthy and moderately active.  I have recently been having pain and stiffness that travels from my shoulder to my fingers, back to my shoulder, etc.  I was not sure where to post this in the other forums, so I am hoping someone will be able to help me.  Or if someone could point me in the right direction, that would be appreciated too.    The pain and stiffness I am experiencing is extremely localized to a certain particular joint.  At the moment, on my right hand, it is difficult to straighten/use my thumb due to the stiffness and when I move it the wrong way, it hurts extremely bad.  On the outside, the skin is red and a little inflamed.  I wake up in the morning like that and it generally lasts for two days or so.  The same type of symptoms also happen with different fingers and my shoulders.  I didn't notice any redness in my shoulders though, but sometimes I would have to use my other arm to push my arm up due to the pain I was experiencing.  I physically could have moved it, however, it hurt so much, I would help it along.  It continues to travel around, one day it could be my right shoulder, next couple days it could be one of my fingers.  Then a couple days later my left shoulder and so on.  This has been happening for about a month and a half.  But it seems that when the pain/stiffness goes away in one area, it comes back in another.  When I massage the area (thinking maybe it was a sore muscle), it seems to swell and feel worse/last longer.  Any thoughts?
posted_time: Post  by albogado » Thu Aug 28, 2008 9:16 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Stiffness and pain that travels
content: Hello, I wonder if you have arthritis.  I would recommend seeing a rheumatologist about this.  There are medications and treatments that are effective.  If it is not arthritis, this doctor can still probably help you to determine the cause and find treatment.  Fibromyalgia can sometimes be a traveling pain but is not usually associated with redness or inflammation.  However, each individual manifests disease in different ways.  Tests and labwork can often give clues about the things that ail you but you have to see a doctor in the flesh to put the whole puzzle together.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: NEVER HAD A PHYSICAL IN ABOUT 10 YEARS
content: Hello, Please know that medical professionals see people of all shapes and sizes.  It may be hard to believe but we truly are able to focus on the body part in need of exam without judging appearance and having inappropriate feelings about it.  It is most important that you have these important health screenings.  Try to see it as part of the healing process, so necessary to getting past the pain you have experienced.  I am glad you are getting help in this area.  Repression of such experiences is common but it is necessary to face the past and work through your feelings in order to go on and be happy in the future.    Try not to focus on what the healthcare provider is thinking about you; but think about how they might be able to help you to have a happier, healthier life.  Talk to your doctor, nurse, etc. about your weight management concerns.  They might be able to help you in that area also.  Obesity is an epidemic and your healthcare team wants to do what is needed to curb this growing problem.  It is not an easy road to travel but you must take care of yourself in all areas.  Let the doctor know you have concerns and that you suffer from PTSD.  They will try to make it as easy as possible if they know what you are worried about.  If you are more comfortable with a woman, that is fine.  There are plenty of good doctors, both male and female, who will treat you with respect and dignity.  Be open and honest with them and allow them to help in any way they can.  Good luck with this.  Many women have had these same struggles.  You are not alone.  Best wishes.

My personal trainer says "you look great for 47, relax".  I am fat.  I know I am fat.  I am out of my BMI.  I can not get the keto stix to hardly change color.  I have headaches all the time, because of this stupid diet.  I am willing to do anything to get this weight off.  I am desperate.  I know that woman my age are getting more and more into anorexia. author: Alexandra C, RN  Nurse Posts: 26 Joined: Fri Mar 14, 2008 3:46 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: wieght loss resistance
content: Dear MeJane47,  First, I want to reassure you that you do not sound borderline psychotic or desperate.  I can understand your frustration, as it sounds you are working very hard to lose weight and feel that the professionals you've consulted have minimized your concerns.  One part of your problem may lie in the fact that our metabolism naturally slows down as we age.  I don't know anything about the diet you describe, but if your calorie intake is low, this will only serve to slow your metabolism down even more.  You said that you have headaches from your diet, so it sounds as if what you are eating is not nutritionally balanced enough to meet your needs.  If it is making you feel bad, and not giving you the result you want, why continue to do it?  I think the suggestion from your doctor that you see a nutritionist is a good one. Diets may help you lose weight initially, but you really need to think about what will work and promote good health over the long-term.  It may be that eating small but nutritionally dense meals frequently will be best in terms of activating your metabolism.  A nutritionist could certainly help you explore how best to get your metabolism going without sacrificing your health.  You also seem really focused on the the numbers on the scale and your BMI.  BMI is a useful tool, but it tends to overestimate fatness in people who have a lot of muscle.  Since you exercise daily I would expect that you probably have a good amount of muscle mass.  It may help you to determine your body fat percentage by a more reliable method, like skinfold measurements.    Also, try to be kind to yourself, and set a goal for better overall health instead of just a number.  You say you would feel great 20 lbs lighter, and while that may be a realistic and attainable goal, you should also feel good about yourself in the body you are in right this minute.  You deserve to feel good about yourself no matter what you weigh, and if you are struggling with this please talk to someone who can help.  Good luck to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: i get chills after change of lifestyle
content: Hello -  It would seem to me that your symptoms are a direct result of the changes in both your lifestye and location/living quarters. It is natural for the body to take some time to acclimatize to a new and different environment, so hopefully the cold feeling and chills will slowly resolve. Make certain the ambient temperature in your sleeping area is at least 65 degrees, and if that's uncomfortable perhaps you can increase it a few degrees to near 70, which should, in time, help your body to become used to the change. Also, trying to become active once again will help because your metabolism is increased (and the body remains somewhat warmer) when you have been active for periods of time during the day, especially if you have the opportunity to do some aerobic activity (if only to take walks) and perhaps using some light free weights. This will actually help you not only to remain fit but also keep you warmer at night.  Good luck to you and please do follow up with us here as needed.

I go to the gym and do the workouts they outline for me and I also hit 5000-6000 calories a day right now, eating 5-7 meals a day.  I guess I fit into the category of a hard gainer. I am curious about 4-Androstenediol, 1-androstenediol, 1-androstene-3beta, and 17beta-diol.  I have read up on these prohormones and from what I can tell the 4-AD seems to be the safest of the bunch, but I don't exactly understand all the chemistry when they are explained.  I am pretty sure someone who may answer this will probably say don't take any probably for possible liability reasons, but if that's the case hypothetically which one should I choose??
posted_time: Post  by ddx50 » Tue Jul 08, 2008 12:09 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: What is the safest prohormone that I can take??
content: Hi Ddx50,  You're correct that I'll say don't take any of them-but it isn't for liability reasons.  These supplements get converted into hormones in the body and carry all the same risks as taking the hormone directly.  In addition, most of these supplements fall under the "herbal" classification and, therefore, are not regulated as tightly as "medications" are, even though they exhibit medicine type effects.  We don't really know all the long term effects of taking these medicines and it is very likely that there are side effects beyond what we know.  It is because of these reasons that I recommend avoiding them.  Best wishes.

content: Hello -  While math is not my strong suit, I think you calculated correctly, which of course is just one reason  why the charcoal therapy hasn't exactly taken off. author: phat_tony  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Fri Feb 29, 2008 12:42 am Gender: Male
title: Release of Toxins Stored in Fat?
content: Hello everyone, this is my first time posting so forgive (and please point out) any transgressions of forum rules!  I have recently began a diet and fitness program. I am burning roughly 1000 to 1300 more calories per day than I take in, according to my best calculations.  I have also been feeling strange. At first I thought it might have been the caloric shortfall, so I decided to ease off my diet for a day or two to see if that made any difference. It has not. I am drinking between 8 and 12 cups of water a day, eating a good carb-protein-fat balance, and exercising regularly, but I still have a strange feeling of dizziness mixed with fatigue (though I get 8 to 9 hours of sleep a night on a fairly regular basis).  I live in Beijing, and have lived here for four years. My apartment faces onto the highly polluted 4th Ring road, and I have lived in it for all 4 years. I remembered just now that toxins taken into your body are stored in your fat cells. Is it possible that burning fat due to my new diet plan could be releasing toxins that I have undoubtedly picked up by living in this city back into my system? Could that account for this feeling?  I have no idea if this is even possible, which is why I am asking you!  Thank you very much for your kind attention.  Tony
posted_time: Post  by phat_tony » Fri Feb 29, 2008 12:58 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Release of Toxins Stored in Fat?
content: Hello, Weight loss diets can cause side effects as you describe.  You should be sure you are getting enough calories for your needs, in a balance of protein, carbs and fats.  Too little can result in tissue damage, so I would recommend the consultation of a nutritionist or dietitian to be sure you are getting enough.  There is no magic calorie number for everyone.  Your own basal metabolic rate can vary and you could need more than your friend next door just to breathe and function at minimal levels.  I'm glad you are conscious of your water intake since dehydration is a serious concern, especially when exercising.  Again this is not a magic number, even though it is commonly said you need 64 ounces a day.  The water does remove toxins and waste so it is important but not enough is known about environmental toxins and the effect they have on the body.  It is known they are harmful but they are so prevalent it is hard to isolate the damage, or even all the specific toxins.  They are everywhere and likely cause us problems with our health in ways we may never know.    Of course there are other causes of dizziness and fatigue so a general physical exam might be in order, including blood work for thyroid, iron, etc.  Dieters do risk having electrolyte imbalance and nutrient deficiencies.  I hope you are taking in a well-balanced diet, even though it is low in calorie.  Good luck with your efforts to improve your health this way.    Best wishes

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Geriatric nutritional requirements
content: Hello, This is a huge challenge.  As we age, our taste buds and appetite both change and it makes eating more of a chore - aside from any other issues such as digestion, teeth condition, etc.  I am of the belief that you must do all you can to get some nutrition in there but forcing foods she does not like will not do any of you any good and may do psychological harm.  I think you have the right idea with small amounts of foods she likes.  If there's a way to supplement some of these with extra calories and nutritional supplements, by all means add these.  You might benefit from a consultation with a registered dietician with experience in geriatric nutrition.  There might be some ideas to help.  Some places also have aging services with nurses and other care providers who specialize in dealing with issues of the aging individual and helping the family members who care for them to find solutions to these challenges.   You might locate such services in your local community or public health agency.    Best wishes.

author: Calla Lily  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Sun May 04, 2008 6:11 am Gender: Female
title: Sugar alcohols raising blood sugar?
content: Do sugar alcohols just as maltitol raise blood sugar?  I'm T2 diabetic and am wonderful how safe it is to eat sugarfree foods that have sugar alcohols in them.
posted_time: Post  by Calla Lily » Tue May 13, 2008 2:07 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Sugar alcohols raising blood sugar?
content: Yes, sugar alcohol is sugar and as such can affect your blood glucose but they are lower on the glycemic index and so they do not cause the same degree of fluctuation as some other sugars.  For example, maltitol has a GI of 36 as opposed to sucrose (sugar) with a GI of 60. Zylitol is only 13 so a much better choice for you.  Calories also vary.  But you must be cautious because these may not be as sweet as other sugars and you may find yourself using more to get the desired taste.    It would be wise to consult with a dietician about your diabetic needs to be sure you are taking care of yourself properly for optimal health.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Mon Jul 07, 2008 8:24 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Should I be taking multivitamins everyday?
content: Hello, It depends on your dietary habits.  If you consistently eat a healthy diet with lots of vegetables, whole grains, protein, and dairy products, while avoiding a lot of junk food, you may not need an additional vitamin.  Most people, however, do not and they benefit from the supplemental vitamin.  It won't hurt to take them regularly but if you miss occasionally, that's OK too.  If you eat poorly, you definitely should take one every day of your life.  It is not a perfect substitute for healthy food but it helps.  The formulas you describe are adequate for most men.  Best wishes.

Is there something that is more beneficial with this rather than other products that are out there?

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: mona vie, is it worth it?
content: Hello, This product is sold as a supplement; not a drug.  As such, we have limited information due to lack of scientific, controlled studies and the only information we really can obtain is produced by the makers of the juice.  I will grant you that it is a well-known fact that fruits are healthy and none of us get enough in our diets typically.  Berries have been shown to be especially beneficial due to their antioxidant properties, anti-cancer benefits, many other vitamins and minerals (even fiber) and they are low in calories.   This juice is made up of many different berries.  As such, it won't hurt you but many people don't eat many berries, claiming they are expensive. Nothing is as expensive as paying someone to bottle up the berries, obtained from tropical sources, who then sell them in a muli-level sales organization with profit going to many different handlers.  Besides this, you miss out on the enjoyment of eating the luscious berries plain or enhancing other foods such as whole grain cereal, yogurt, nuts, etc. which boost the health benefits of the berries themselves.   This is no magical cure for everything that ails you as some distributors suggest.  If it were me, I would stock up on strawberries, blueberries and any other fruits and vegetables you like for the same benefit but giving you much more variety.  At $3 a day, one person can enjoy a lot of nice fruit.   With summer coming, fruits will be available at farmer's markets and local groceries at a good price.  Buy and enjoy fresh, which is known to provide the most benefit.  Freeze some more for the winter or buy dried or frozen later.  If you like a mixed berry juice, throw them in the blender.  I see nothing contained in this product that can be proven to have medicinal or weight-loss properties though we would all love to find such a thing.  I don't believe it is a scam unless you buy into the idea that it has magic properties.  I do agree it is an expensive way to get healthy berries into your diet.  People have the right to sell berries in any form as long as they are handled in a hygienic way.  We pay a lot for convenience foods and this may be seen as one of those, with the addition of some tropical berries that you won't find in the local grocery.    If those tropical berries were all they claim to be, don't you think major universities and researchers would have jumped on it and investigated those properties?  Mainstream medicine is as anxious as nutritionists to find cures for cancer, obesity, and other disorders.  I would be skeptical of exaggerated claims.    There are other similar products available as well - not just Mona Vie.  I would apply the same precautions to the others.    Best wishes.

title: Re: Weight Gain Shortcuts?
content: Hello, There is a certain amount of genetic predisposition for body size that is almost impossible to change.  If your body style is lean and thin, nothing you do will make a huge impact.  This does not mean you are unhealthy so as Dr. Lowe has suggested, making healthy life choices is the most important thing to getting the best body you can have, whatever shape that is.    Eating a nutrient-rich diet is the best thing you can do.  You may need to learn to accept your body type.  Many large people have similar frustrations as they diet and reduce calories drastically, often with limited results.  They just are not able to overcome their basic body shape, but they can become healthier with good choices.    You can build muscle mass with workouts.  You could consult with a personal trainer to optimize your results.  If you supplement, make sure you do it safely and don't expect a magic pill, potion or powder.  It doesn't hurt to discuss your concerns with your doctor to be sure there is no underlying physical disorder.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: penicillin - weight
content: Hello James,  Penicillin is not ordered in the typical milligram dosing.  Instead, it is ordered in units and often a typical dose will be in the hundreds of thousands or million units.  It may be that the large dose you were given was actually a very appropriate dose.  It is very unlikely that you have had any problems from the penicillin, especially since the problem appears to be a little more recent in onset (rather than very soon after the penicillin).  I would recommend you continue to follow up with your doctor to help evaluate this.  If you have not had your thyroid levels checked I would recommend this.  If you are having any problems with abdominal pain, diarrhea or even constipation I would recommend you consider seeing a GI specialist for evaluation of possible malabsorption problems.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: I'm never hungry
content: Hello, You definitely should see a doctor to see if there is some underlying physical symptom that is altering your appetite.  I assume this is a fairly new development for you but if you are new to the military it could also be related to your abrupt change of lifesyle, stress and increased exercise.  If you doctor finds no physical cause, there is the possibility is is psychological.  This does not mean it isn't real; just that the source may be in your subconscious mind or related to some unresolved issues.  In this case, therapy might be helpful.  You should be able to get both physical and psychological treatment through the military.  There are MANY possible causes for loss of appetite and sometimes your doctor must just go through the list ruling out each possible condition.  This can involve the endocrine system, GI disorders, drugs, psychiatric causes, kidney disease, diabetes and sometimes no cause can be identified.  In that case you must force yourself to get the nutrition you need with dietary supplements.    Good luck with this.  I am glad you are aware of this as a problem before the weight loss gets more significant and you put your health in danger.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Bigger Breasts?
content: Hello, Breast size is mostly determined genetically and affected at times by hormonal fluctuation so this is probably what is happening here. Usually your own breasts will be stabilized by six years after the menarche (start of menstruation).  Too bad we can't really manipulate it though because many women would like to be able to get a natural enlargement.  I would not be alarmed unless you noticed lactation (without breastfeeding happening). This could indicate a problem with a pituitary gland.  If you find you continue to notice changes over time, you should see your doctor to check out your hormone levels.    Best wishes

title: How can I gain weight?
content: I am 5'5" and weigh only 85 pounds. I eat all the time, and just can't seem to gain weight. I was wondering if there was a healthy way in which I could gain about 20-25 lbs. in three or four months?
posted_time: Post  by brit010188 » Sun Feb 24, 2008 3:45 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: How can I gain weight?
content: Hello, Isn't it frustrating that there is so much distress on either end of the weight spectrum.  People on one end (the majority) are fighting excess weight and others on the other side of the field are fighting to gain.  Just doesn't seem fair, does it?  For both conditions, heredity plays a very large role and this can make it most difficult to change the body type.    The best thing you can do is add healthy foods to your diet while exercising.  You aim for muscle mass; not fat, so exercise and body building are important even when you want to gain.  I would recommend a visit with a registered dietician to plan a good program for you based on your likes and needs.  Health food stores do sell supplemental protein drink powders that have a high caloric count and help some people.  I can't recommend any one in particular but you might inquire at such a specialty store.    Keep in mind though, it is likely that you will not be able to make huge gains here because of your particular genetically determined body type.  Rather than trying too hard to get a different body, try to be appreciative of the advantages your type has and be sure you are as healthy as possible through positive life choices, food choices and activity.  Then you will know you have done all that is possible.  I know many very thin people (as well as many very heavy people) who are comfortable with who they are and have accepted the limitations of their body type even though it is not what they have chosen.  This is healthy.   Good luck.

posted_time: Post  by amanda.marie73 » Mon Feb 25, 2008 11:27 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Hip to Waist Ratio vs. BMI
content: Hello Amanda.marie73,  Both BMI and hip:waste ratio are guidelines to help categorize health risks; however, they both must be balanced with all the other health assessment factors.  I would suggest you talk with your doctor about your overall health assessment.  I would suggest you test your cholesterol to be sure it is at a healthy level.  Also, I would recommend you start or continue an exercise program.  Make sure your diet is healthy.    If you balance your diet, exercise, and the other health factors the hip:waste ratio and BMI become less significant.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: How long will you live?
content: Hello BigDady91288,  Unfortunately, it is not possible for me to answer this question.  The average life expectancy for a woman is around 80 years old.  Many factors impact this including illnesses and overall health status.  The difficult part is that there is nothing that accurately predicts survival.  Even those in poor health can manage to live well beyond the "average" life expectancy.  Other times, those in peak health die much before expected.  My best advice for you is to try to optimize your health as this will also optimize your life expectancy as much as possible.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: possible hernia from obesity
content: Hello Shylea,  It is very possible that you have developed a hernia.  Previous surgery incision sites are prime locations to develop hernias.  I would recommend that you have this evaluated if at all possible.  While you may not be having pain now, if this is a hernia there is always the possibility that the intestines may become twisted.  If this happens it becomes a surgical emergency and the repair is much more risky than repairing the hernia before there is a problem with the intestines.  Best wishes.

title: Re: Ingesting too much sugar
content: Hello Connerse,  In an otherwise healthy person, there is unlikely to be any danger to this.  The biggest issue is the sugar load, which can be handled appropriately by a healthy body.  In someone with a condition such as diabetes this could be more severe.  This would add up to a lot of calories so clearly it is not a good idea to do repeatedly but if someone has ingested a whole bottle they are likely to not have any problems other than possibly some nausea. author: justme816  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Wed Jan 02, 2008 8:50 pm
title: Omega 3 - How much is enough?
content: I heard that omega 3 is great to take for depression and anxiety. I recently purchased an omega 3 supplement and it has 1,000 mg of fish oil, 500mg of (EPA)  and 75 mg of (DHA). Whould this be safe to take every day or should i just take it every other day? I have no other health issues.  I'm 24 years old.... 5'6" and 120 pounds.  Thanks for your advice!
posted_time: Post  by justme816 » Thu Jan 10, 2008 4:36 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Omega 3 - How much is enough?
content: Hello, Since this falls more in the supplement category rather than medication, the FDA has not issued a recommendation.  Nutritionists generally say between one and four grams daily is most beneficial but it varies depending on what health issue you are addressing.  That is a pretty wide range.  It has also been reported that getting this from food sources is actually better for absorption than supplements.  Of course in calculating the amount you need to take into account what you get from foods containing the Omega 3 fatty acids.  Fish are the best source for this but some large fish (Tile, swordfish, king makarel, etc.) have been associated with higher levels of mercury contamination so some caution should be used particularly in pregnant women and children but other than this I see nothing that warns of any need to restrict to every other day dosing in health individuals who do not have disorders involving bleeding, who bruise very easily, or who are taking blood thinners.  These folks should consult with a medical practitioner before taking supplemental omega 3 fatty acids.  If you are in the USA, keep in mind the FDA does not regulate supplements as they do other medications.  They have, however, acknowledged the important health benefits of a diet rich in the Omega 3s.   I have not found anything indicating the amount nutritionists recommend specifically for treating depression and anxiety.  The safest way to get this is in foods that contain naturally high levels of the nutrient.  There are other non-prescription treatments for depression and anxiety.  You may be interested in a book called, When Your Body Gets the Blues by Marie Annette Brown and Jo Robinson for other ideas.  Best wishes to you.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Wed Feb 06, 2008 7:29 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: A lifelong struggle.
content: The first thing that comes to mind is the possibility of anemia.  Women your age are susceptible and vegans are particularly so.  You should consult a good nutritionist if  you choose to eat this way because it is difficult to get all the nutrients you need - not impossible, but it takes great effort and planning.  Your doctor could do a simple test for anemia because you may need iron supplements as well.    Of course there are other common causes for tiredness such as thyroid disorder.  It is also known that most people do require at least 8 hours sleep regularly and most people do not get enough.    Are you taking any medications?  Do you feel prone to depression?  These can also have tiredness as a side effect.  As you mentioned, major life events can cause stress which may also be manifest as depression symptoms so if you have access to a counselor, perhaps through school, you might benefit from a psychological  evaluation as well.  Taking on an exercise program is commendable but it may take a while for you to achieve results.  Try to stay with it and lengthen the time gradually until you build up to a good, regular pace.  I could also recommend a book, When Your Body Gets the Blues by Dr. Marie-Annette Brown and Jo Robinson.  They offer some excellent ideas to help yourself through some of these symptoms.  Best wishes to you.

author: jacluc  Guest Posts: 13 Joined: Sat Apr 28, 2007 7:31 pm
title: hypotonia and hypometabolism
content: My son is 5 years old and was born with hypotonia and is gross motor developmentally delayed.  The cause of the hypotonia was never found although we were seen by a genetisist, endocrinologist, neurologist, cardiologist, you name it we were there.  He was born large at 10 pounds 8 ounces and 22 and a half inches long.  It seems that every year he goes through a tremendous weight gain between the months of September and January.  Last year during this gain (I believe he gained 8 pounds during that time last year) he was tested for thyroid disease and diabetes, both were negative.  This fall it started again with a total weight gain of 10 pounds from his July physical until now.  Obviously this is alarming.  The pediatrician suggested a nutrionalist.  I have an appointment for next week but in the mean time was told to try to cut calories.  This child does not over eat.  He doesn't snack on chips or cookies.  He eats raw peppers, grapes, stawberries, things like that.  He doesn't eat a lot of fast food, he can't even finish a happy meal from Mc Donalds.  He does eat a lot of pasta in his diet.  The hypotonia has affected his mouth and tongue and he has a really bad gag reflex and poor chewing ability so pasta was always easy for him to handle.  I spoke with a nutrionist over the phone who said that his poor muscle tone may be causing hypometabolism.  Have you ever heard of that?  I would appreciate any suggestions on how to cut calories without starving him.  He is currently 70 pounds and 4 feet tall.
posted_time: Post  by jacluc » Fri Dec 28, 2007 1:00 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: hypotonia and hypometabolism
content: Hi Jacluc,  Your description of your son makes me wonder about a syndrome called Prader-Willi syndrome.  Has he been evaluated for this?    Regarding the hypometabolism, if a child is undernurished (even if he is eating a lot) the body can start to move into a starvation phase where it will slow down its metabolism.  At this point, it takes less calories to meet the body's demand so any excess calories will be stored as fat for later use if the starvation continues.  If, by chance, your son is deficient in protein, etc. and mostly getting carbohydrates (from pasta) then it is possible that he has become hypometabolic.  However, this usually occurs in the case of total undernurishment.  If he is still getting a lot of calories but is missing only one part (such as protein) he is much less likely to move into this state.  In this case, other symptoms would begin to develop such as abdominal swelling from excess fluid in the abdomen.  Seeing a nutritionist is a good idea.  I think it sounds like your child needs further evaluation medically as well.  I would recommend he have speech swallow study to see if he is able to safely eat various types of food (solid, liquid, etc.).  He may also need evaluation for a G-tube to help give him nutrition that is properly balanced if he is not sufficiently able to do this orally.  Follow up with a pediatrician is very important.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Fri Jan 18, 2008 8:29 pm

He is not a big snacker but his diet really did consist of pretty much pasta, fruit, and some vegetables with the pasta being the heaviest component.  This all makes sense to me but I am not a doctor.  Does this sound like we could be on the right track?

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Concerns on weight loss pills and injections
content: This is not treatment I am familiar with in the U.S.  It may be used but it is not mainstream medicine and I tend to be a bit cautious about alternative and possibly experimental treatments, especially after the Phen-fen problem a few years back.  I have become quite leary about anything that appears to be a quick and easy fix for weight loss.  It take work, self-control, exercise, sensible dietary changes or surgery in the case of morbid obesity.  Anything else seems to be temporary.  I would suggest you discuss with the doctor in detail about the risks and benefits of this treatment and learn whether there are good scientific studies to support the treatment before embarking on this course yourself. Good luck.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: questions concerning liquid diet for weightloss..
content: Hello, It just depends on the diet you are using.  There are very effective liquid diets that are available by prescription which are complete in nutrition and can cause rapid but safe weight loss.  They are prescription to be sure they are used under a doctor's care, who can evaluate your physical health and determine if you have any underlying conditions that would make this risky.  Three weeks is a pretty safe time frame and if the liquid diet contains the nutrition you need, it should be safe.  Any time you make such a drastic change in your diet, your bowel function can be affected.  Constant diarrhea could put you in a state of dehydration, which can be very serious so drinking lots of water would be essential.  I would recommend a medical evaluation but if you are in good health, the limited use of this product is likely to be perfectly safe.  Long-term might be another story. If you need a kick-start for rapid loss, this might be an answer.    As an alternative, you could probably be just as successful with a very strict diet that is high in protein and almost zero carbs (except those you get with vegetables).  Eat strictly lean meats, beans and vegetables with limited fats and eliminate refined carbs completely (breads, starches, sugars).  That will give you a good jump start on the weight loss.  Then you can gradually add whole grains after the three week period.  For long term success, you would be wise to avoid the processed and refined sugars and breads for en extended period.  Your body does not need these.  Note, I am not saying you do not need carbohydrates but vegetables supply ample amounts for a healthy diet.    Best wishes and congratulations on your desire to obtain a healthy body weight.

author: pp5k  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Jan 02, 2008 1:48 pm
title: How can I gain Height?
content: I'm a 16 year old boy, I'm only 5feet 3, and i want to grow taller, is there any nutritious plan that i can do in my remaining years of growth that will definately help me grow tall? By the way, how many years do I have till i stop growing? thanks
posted_time: Post  by pp5k » Wed Jan 02, 2008 2:02 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: How can I gain Height?
content: Hi, Most boys stop growing in height around age 16 but there are exceptions.  I know of some boys who added inches when they were 20 but this is not the norm.  Genetics plays a large role in this and nutritional status contributes as well.  I also know of some boys who ate extremely healthy meals as a child who surpassed their parents' height be quite a bit.  Is it the diet?  Nobody knows for sure but we do know it plays a role so you can't lose by adding lots of vegetables, fruits, and dairy products to your diet.  We have recently learned how really valuable this is.  The average teen's diet is not rich in these nutrients since french fries hardly count.  Other than an overall balanced eating plan, I know of no supplements that will increase your growth.    It is possible for you to have a checkup with your doctor to evaluate if you have a human growth hormone deficiency - not because greater height is desired, but to determine if there is a lack that could affect other aspects of your health.  In order to affect height, treatment for this disorder begins at a relatively young age so I'm not sure how you might relate to this but an evaluation by a doctor is recommended for boys your age anyway.  Please schedule an appointment for a complete physical exam with your pediatrician or family doctor.  Explain your concerns to him or her.  I understand your desire to be taller but I hope you will also focus on other aspects of your mind and body, realizing that the size and worth of a man go beyond his appearance.  You can also work to develop your muscles and this will help your self image.  I don't mean aspiring to be "Mr. America" - just strength and muscle in place of flab.  It will improve your overall health too.  This goes a long way to being physically appealing.  As a short person myself, I do realize the areas of frustration but don't let your quest for inches become the dominant force in your life.      Best wishes for your successful future - in all your endeavors.

title: Constipation with blood
content: To whom it may concern  I have become constipated with feces stuck in the colon. When trying to pass it, blood is coming out of the anus. It has been recommended to take a pint of pure orange juice. Will this work and how long would it take  Regards, Man In need
posted_time: Post  by mccay_a » Sun Dec 30, 2007 2:30 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Constipation with blood
content: Hello, You may need to take a laxative such as milk of magnesia.  Sometimes impacted bowels must have manual removal of the feces.  A glycerine suppository can help soften the stool.  A gloved finger is used with a lubricant such as mineral oil to prevent trauma to the rectum.  Gentle prodding is used to break up the stool into manageable bits. It is difficult to do yourself and may require the help of a healthcare provider.    Prevention is the best cure.  Changing diet (avoid starch and meat, increase whole grains, fruits and vegetables) and adding lots of water along with fiber supplements such as Konsyl (psyllium), Metamucil and Citracel can do a lot of good.  But you must deal with the problem at hand.  The blood is due to trauma in the attempt to pass the large stool or from hemorrhoids which are also caused or aggravated by constipation.    I have never heard of orange juice curing this condition but the extra fluids and fiber won't hurt. Good luck.

title: excessive hunger

This sudden hunger happens not every day but several times a month.  What could be wrong with me?  I get regular physicals, but I am due for one. posted_time: Post  by yorubam » Sat Dec 08, 2007 10:32 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: excessive hunger
content: Hello, This is a very frustrating problem.  There are hormones and chemicals in the body that affect a person's metabolism and fat accumulation.  This is one area of life that just isn't fair.  One person will fight to gain, while (more often) others fight to lose.  A good, well-rounded diet is your best option but sometimes you can kick start with something like a high protein/no refined carbs program.  Avoid all sugars, processed foods and take in lean meats, beans, vegetables, some fats but avoid grains, flour (breads, etc.)  You can get your body into ketosis where fat stores are used and it helps get things started.  Later you can carefully and gradually add back in dense carbohydrates such as a few whole grains.  You might consider joining a program such as Weight Watchers where you can also get emotional and social support in your efforts.  These are safe diets and when followed along with exercise produce good and lasting results.  The problem is people give up on these plans too soon.    As for the hunger that comes "too soon" it could be you need to break your meals down into small servings that you take more frequently.  You do want to avoid the ravishing hunger that can come from waiting too long.  Have some healthy snacks (especially vegetables) handy to eat when you get that sensation.  Also, drink lots of water!  Many times our body is craving water but it feels like hunger.  Good luck.

author: zakkenya  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Dec 28, 2007 1:17 pm
title: I need a prescribed diet pill that WORKS..SUGGESTIONS
content: Please tell me what kinds of prescribed pills work...I am visiting a doctor after the new year and I want to suggest one that I have researched....
posted_time: Post  by zakkenya » Fri Dec 28, 2007 1:25 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: I need a prescribed diet pill that WORKS..
content: Hello, I certainly understand your desire and if there was a magic bullet here, someone would be very rich right now.  There are some things that help but they are only aids to help such as Orlistat that blocks fat absorption but it is not without its side effects and can cause diarrhea if you take in too much fat.  So this can be helpful in conjunction with a good diet program.    Sibutramine (marketed as Meridia) is also effective for many people but it can raise blood pressure so some are not candidates for it.  Also, this drug is used as an appetite suppressant in conjunction with a weight loss diet and some people find it's effects to be temporary so it is best used in weight loss needs of maybe up to 50 pounds in a dedicated dieter.  Once the effects are diminished as the person develops tolerance, the weight may come back on unless good eating habits have replaced the old ones.    I'm sure you are aware that FenPhen should not be used but some people do find success with just the phentermine, which is safe (half of the combination).  The use of the two together was found to be damaging to some people's heart valves.    There are also some drug studies going on to try new medications so if you have such research agencies in your area, that might be another route to try.    Whatever you do, combine it with an exercise program for greatest success.  If you are morbidly obese you might also consider weight loss surgery such as gastric bypass or gastric banding procedures.   Programs such as Weight Watchers, TOPS, Overeaters Anonymous, hypnotherapy, etc. are also shown to be quite helpful.  You may find a multi-disciplinary approach to work best.  Best wishes for improved health through your diligent efforts.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Fri Dec 28, 2007 4:02 pm

author: tfaranas  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Dec 26, 2007 7:45 am
title: 5-HTP and Ginkgo Biloba together?
content: hi, want to know if it is safe to take in together natrol 5-htp and nature's resources Ginkgo biloba?  is it true that these meds help reduce weight?  please advice as i have started taking these two meds together and don't have an idea if it's safe.  best regards
posted_time: Post  by tfaranas » Wed Dec 26, 2007 8:15 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: 5-HTP and Ginkgo Biloba together?
content: Hello,  The products you inquire about are not actually in the category of medications as in drugs regulated by the FDA in the U.S.  They are supplements and as such there are not strict testing requirements for purity, consistent product content, evidence of effectiveness and safety.  While I am not saying that the FDA is perfect in its regulatory capacity, at least there is more consistency and we can be more sure that a product is what it claims to be.  Supplements fall in a different category and Information about whether or not these work for weight loss could be coming from their own manufacturer and may not have been proven scientifically so use at your own risk.  Many people are confused when something is made from "natural" ingredients.  Because it occurs naturally in nature does not guarantee its safety when ingested or otherwise introduced into the human body.  This is not to say that supplements are not safe but you must do your own investigation and I would encourage using only brands from reputable supplement manufacturers to best assure that you are getting what they claim you are.  Random checks have revealed a wide array of ingredients and amounts included that are not what they claim.  So, when dealing with a drug that is not regulated (supplement) you must be more careful.  I know this is what you are asking for here, but without sanctioned, unbiased studies of large enough magnitude to be reliable, we cannot advise.    Here is the information I found:  "Do not use 5-HTP is you are currently taking any of the following medications: Anti-depressant drugs; Monoamine oxidase inhibitors; Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors; Tricyclic medications; Weight Loss medications; Anti-parkinson medications; Barbiturates and other tranquilizing drugs; Antihistamines and cold medications; Alcoholic beverages; Intravenous drugs; Cancer chemotherapy or antibiotic medications.  Warning: Dosages of 5-hydroxy L-tryptophan (5-HTP) greater than 100 milligrams per day should be taken only under the guidance of a physician."  Ginko Bilboa is not listed here so evidently it has not been found to be a problem to date.  Use caution whenever you take medications, including supplements.  Don't exceed the recommended dosage, report supplements you use to  your doctor just as you would other drugs when asked what you take as part of your health history.  Use reputable brands you can trust and inquire through the nutritional suppliers about any testing they can report so you can make an informed decision.   This is about the best you can do since we can't tap into reliable regulatory information sources on these drugs.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Wed Dec 26, 2007 11:34 am

I have had a bit of a hoarsey and phlegmy cough lately, but its mainly been the tiedness and a few headaches. I don't even do all that much in the day at the moment either. I have often had afternoon naps where I have fallen fully asleep, and at these times and at night I often have very vivid dreams.  I do grind my teeth a lot at night too, but I have a mouth guard now. There is no particular huge stress in my life causing this that I can think of. I'm just sick of being so tired all the time!
posted_time: Post  by avdb_ » Sun Dec 23, 2007 9:16 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Always tired
content: Hi Avdb_,  I suspect that you have a viral infection causing your fatigue.  The classic viral infection causing fatigue is mononucleosis (caused by Ebstein Barr virus).  Anemia and hypothyroidism can also cause these symptoms.  Another possibility would be that even though you are sleeping at night you may not be getting quality sleep.  Conditions such as sleep apnea can rob a person of their sleep so that, even though they are sleeping, they don't get a good solid sleep so during the day fatigue sets in.  I would suggest you see your doctor for an evaluation and possibly some screening tests to help figure out why you are feeling this way.  Best wishes.

content: Hi Jsaema,  Depending on the brand of soda, typical caffeine amounts in a 12 ounce can range from about 35 to about 55 mg of caffeine, with most being in the upper 30's or lower 40's.  Assuming 40mg/can, drinking 5-6 cans will give 200 to 240 mg/day.  So, the caffeine content of either method is going to be about the same.  Taking the caffeine pill and drinking water is probably better from this stand point since drinking soda will also give other compounds that would not be present in the water.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello, You are most likely losing hair because of the bulemia.  You said BMI of 17 is not low but it is definitely underweight and your body is perceiving malnutrition.  When it does this it conserves the minimal energy it has for the more vital organs - brain, lungs, heart.  It will sacrifice the organs that are less critical - hair, nails, even fingers, toes, etc.  So, the best thing you can do is get treatment for your bulemia.  See a psychiatrist immediately if you haven't already.    There are no magic vitamins that can completely replace nutrition through eating.  Many ill patients in the hospital have to rely on tube feedings and they too lack what they need for optimal health.  The liquid vitamins they receive in the hospital are the best that are available but they still don't really cut it.  It's better than nothing but their bodies suffer in many ways.  The B vitamins are usually implicated for hair and nails but again, if you don't get adequate caloric intake and your electrolytes are messed up through vomiting and/or induced diarrhea you will not be able to compensate.  There is no magic bullet, shampoo, treatment or potion that will fix this problem.  There are other causes of hair loss such as alopecia arreata but with your history, I would first suspect nutrition.  Please get the intense therapy that may be required to lick this problem.  My prayers are with you for success in this difficult situation.  Best wishes. Debbie

title: Never feel full, Always tired
content: I apologize if this post would better belong in a different part of the forum but I was unsure.   I am a 21 year old white female. I have never had surgery and haven't been diagnosed. I had believed that my sleep issues might have been caused my my sudden shift to a 3rd shift sleeping schedule but even swapping back hasn't helped. I can sleep for 12 hours, and am ready to go back to bed after only a few hours awake.  I'm hoping that by posting on these forums someone can point me in the right direction. I would like to go to a doctor about this but am not sure if I should go to a specialist or not. Can someone please PLEASE tell me were I can go for help with this? The excessive sleeping and eating have been putting a strain on my marriage and are starting to make me depressed.  I thank you for any information you might be able to give me.  God Bless  Kayla

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi, Congratulations on your desire to lose weight prior to pregnancy.  If you can, it will greatly decrease your risks of complications.    As for Alli, this is a very new drug to assist with weight loss and I doubt there is enough data to know how pregnancy will be affected by this, if at all.    Since drugs are not tested on pregnant women, the only way we can get data is by collecting information on women who have taken the medication while pregnant.  After following the pregnancy, along with thousands of others with the same situation, we are able to get a pretty good idea of safety (at least if it raises the risk of birth defects beyond the normal 3 - 5%).  New drugs such as this one will be limited in information but if you have a local teratology service, such as otispregnancy.org you may be able to get some information, if somewhat limited.     If your weight loss attempts are not successful, I would keep gastric bypass in mind as a good alternative since it has been shown to be very successful in the long term, but it is recommended the patient does not become pregnant until they are at least 18 months post-surgery.  So, if you are planning pregnancy soon, this would not be a good time for the weight loss surgery.  Good luck in your efforts

author: codyhuntersierra  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sat Oct 20, 2007 4:11 pm
title: Weight and Depression
content: Hi, I'm a 21 year old female with a weight problem. I'm 5'6 and weigh a little over 220 lbs, (varies from 218-226). Growning up, I never had a huge weight problem, I ate whatever I wanted and exercised only when it was required by the sports I was involved in. My parents were both a little overweight, but it was becuase of their unhealthy habits... a little extra mayo hold the work-out. I was married in 2004, and within the first year of my marriage I gained 80lbs. Since I got married, I was eating nothing but nutritious foods and exercising 4-5 days a week. I was more healthy then, than I was in my entire life, and yet I was gaining weight! I went to see a nutritionist to see if I had a thyroid problem, or another explaination for my delimma. I did all kinds of tests, blood work, & food and exercise journals just for the huge dissapointment of hearing 'it all looks good, I don't know what to tell you'. I continued to watch what I ate and exercise every time I got a chance, but I was maintaining my weight, at best.     I moved about a year ago and was getting really frustrated with my self image. Never do I want to be a barbie doll, but I want to look healthy. 160lbs would be just fine with me. It was keeping me up at night until I would cry myself to sleep in anger and frustration. Finally I decided to see another nutritionist at my current location. Again, we did the logging, the blood tests, the works. I was eating less than 1000 calories a day (of only whole grains, mostly fruits and veggies and lean meats) and running 30 min each morning mon-fri then doing a gym (40 min cardio and 20 min weights) work-out on mon-wed afternoons. Logic would only deduct that if you consume less calories than you burn, you will loose weight. Well, that is not working, and the doctor saw that. Though the tests all came back normal, again, he gave me the option of perscription medication. I am on Phemtermine now. I told my doc here that I did not want anything that would suppress my appetite, as I was already not eating enough. However, with phentermine, I am eating less in a week than most people eat in a day. I consume less than 500 calories a day, (though I think thats a high guess as I will go a couple days in a row without consuming anything but black coffee and water) honest-to-God. It's not that I choose not to eat, in fact, I am never hungry. I eat the 500 calories that I do because I force myself. I still have the same workout schedule, and yes, it is rigorous, if I'm not sweating, I push harder. Though the Phen has worked a bit, it is with little result.    I don't know what else to do. I have gone into a really deep depression. I don't feel comfortable in my own skin. I sleep for 4 hours a night if I'm lucky, and I hide myself from the world. I have always been a happy-go-lucky person. I've lost interest in so many things. I am trying so hard to lose weight to be at a healthy weight but nothing works. If I cannot find something that works, I fear I won't be around much longer. This is not by any means in terms of suicide, but eating so little and working out so much cannot be good for my body. I fear I will do permanent damage to my body if I do not find a better solution soon.    Help, what can I do? I need to loose weight because it prevents me from doing things I love, and it does not look professional. What else can I possibly try to get this weight off?  P.S. I'm also on minocycline for acne, which has only made it worse, and prilosec for heartburn.
posted_time: Post  by codyhuntersierra » Sat Oct 20, 2007 4:39 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello, I can certainly understand your frustration.  It sounds like you have some kind of genetic predisposition to weight gain.  It is possible you might be a candidate for weight loss surgery (Gastric bypass of one type or other that inhibits absorption; as opposed to limiting amounts like the lap band would do).  You may not meet the criteria and insurance coverage varies since some consider this health issue to be merely cosmetic, but it might be worth looking into.      It sounds like you have tried everything to no avail.  I would also recommend you get treatment for the depression.  This is very real, no matter what the triggering event is.  It results from inadequate neurotransmitter function and often needs medication to get better.  Seeing a therapist about this could also be helpful.    I assume  your doctor has also checked you for PCOS (Polycystic ovary syndrome).  This can result in unexplained weight gain.  Acne is sometimes caused by this as well.  There is a relationship with insulin and other endocrine functions but it might be worth checking.  I would also recommend a book called, When Your Body Gets the Blues by by Marie Annette Brown and Jo Robinson.  While the book discusses overeating, it is excellent in terms of tendency to gain weight and the depression that often accompanies it.  Please let us know what you find out.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello, I'm sorry to hear you are experiencing negative side effects with this preparation.  As for flushing out, I know of no answer there other than allowing your body to rid itself naturally over time.  How long is anyone's guess.  By way of information, herbal products and supplements are not regulated and tested by the FDA in the U.S. so there are not good studies to show safety.  When a product in this category claims safety, it is by its own standards and it may or may not be safe.  There is no tru regulation of this industry to guarantee even that the product is what it claims to be.  As for diet pills, there are hundreds on the market because everyone is trying to get on the moneymaking bandwagon that has resulted from our obesity epidemic.  In truth, if there were safe and effective diet pills without side effects, we would be all over it.  The doctors would prescribe it because they want their patients to be healthy and overweight is not healthy.  I would recommend staying away from these oft-advertised gimmicks in the future.  Consult with your doctor about weight loss alternatives or use a tried and true method where a prescribed diet of less calories than what you expend are taken in, combined with a regular exercise program.  This is the only real way to lose weight safely.  If you are morbidly obese, there are other options as well.  Your doctor will know about these too.  Good luck.
